We embrace disability not just as a personal experience but also as a site of justice work nationally and globally. We aim to foster a sense of community among students with disabilities, share resources for navigating YSPH with a disability, advocate for members of our community, and promote structural transformation.

name: Disabled Law Students Association
mission:
The Disabled Law Students Association is a law student affinity group comprised of communities situated within a broad disability umbrella. Our community includes disabled students, neurodivergent students, students with learning impairments or non-traditional learning styles, deaf students, hard-of-hearing students, blind students, deaf-blind students, students with chronic illnesses, students with mental health conditions or emotional disorders, and other students who receive or would like to receive accommodations.
We define our affinity group broadly, welcoming anyone who identifies as a member. Our aim is to foster a sense of community and increase the legal profession's accessibility and cultural competency surrounding disability. We provide individualized support to our members in accessing accommodations and ensuring their needs are being met at the law school, in internships, and across other contexts. It is our hope that, through our organization, our members can support each other in navigating the legal profession.

name: DivineAbilities
mission: Our goal is to create a space of fellowship and support for people with disabilities, physical disabilities, mental illnesses, chronic illnesses, temporary disabilities, and learning disabilities. We advocate on behalf of current and future disabled students through policy change and institutional compliance with said policy at YDS and Yale. We recognize that many with disabilities and chronic illnesses do not feel like they have a place within religious institutions or have had pain surrounding their experiences. We want to provide justice and reconciliation for disabled people who have experienced systemic discrimination within faith communities. We strive to have courageous conversations about equity and the allocation of resources toward eliminating barriers at Yale. We offer opportunities for allies to utilize their privilege to work toward alleviating the labor, pain, and stress involved in fighting for disability equity. Lastly, we work with faculty to create academic programming that centers and uplifts disabilities and its intersections.

name: Divinity Colloquium
mission: Our mission is to provide a forum dedicated to the fostering of collective academic conversation at Yale Divinity School. The Divinity Colloquium seeks to offer monthly sessions with a semi-formal yet low-pressure environment, during which students may present their work to an audience of fellow students. The Colloquium might take a form such as a discussion of a pre-circulated draft or a practice version of a conference talk. The ultimate aim of the Colloquium will be to provide a regularly convening venue wherein students may present their work to their peers while receiving suggestions, constructive criticisms, praise, and that overall collective academic experience that should define graduate school.

name: Divinnovation
category: Advocacy/Policy, Entrepreneurial/Business, International Affairs, Leadership, Political, Pre-Professional, Professional, Religious/Spiritual, Science/Technology, Social, Speech/Debate, International, Tsai CITY Affiliate Org
mission: Divinnovation (a linguistic braiding of "Divinity" and "innovation") is an organization that offers an interdisciplinary space where students can explore and collaborate at the intersections of theology, social entrepreneurship, law, business, and other non-traditional ministries. We foster innovation through relationship building, practical skill development, and community entrepreneurial events. Divinnovation maintains a partnership with the Tsai Center for Innovative Thinking at Yale (Tsai CITY). The organization seeks to develop alumni and cross-campus ecosystems to support the faith-based projects and social impact work of future leaders emerging from YDS.

name: Global Alliance for Public Health
mission: We strive to create a space for the academic and professional development of international students at the Yale School of Public Health and truly bring diverse and global voices to the public health field.

name: DivOut
mission: DivOut is a space for the LGBTQ+ students, faculty, and staff of Yale Divinity School to join together in community. We are committed to care for one another, to seek justice, and to work for the full inclusion of all people, especially queer people, within spiritual communities. We recognize that the fight for queer liberation must be centered around ideals of intersectionality and we are committed to collective liberation. DivOut holds social, educational, and spiritual events throughout the school year with these values in mind. We continue to remember that YDS, as a historically Christian space, has not always been welcoming to queer members of its community and continues to hold room for growth. We aim to put continued pressure on the leaders of this institution to ensure that YDS is a safe and welcoming space for all students, faculty, and staff.

name: DocComm SIG
mission:
DocComm is the branch of the Student Affairs Committee comprised of and representing the doctoral (graduate and postdoctoral students) community:
1.	Mission: The Student Affairs Committee (SAC) is an elected body of active students at the Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies (F&ES). SAC is dedicated to facilitating communication and understanding among the F&ES student body, administration, and staff; advocating on behalf of the student body on pressing issues; supporting student interest groups and executing a limited number of official duties.
2.	Principles: SAC is designed to be a cooperative, non-hierarchical, transparent, and nimble body. SAC will not discriminate based on age, gender, marital status, sexual orientation, race, color, creed, religion, national origin, political orientation, or physical abilities, and will actively strive to combat discrimination in all its forms. SAC strives to include the interest of the F&ES community including current students, administration, staff, alumni, and the broader Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Doox of Yale
mission: Doox of Yale is an a cappella group founded in 1952 by Basil "Duke" Henning, former head of Saybrook College. The first tenor/bass group at Yale to become all-gender, Doox prides itself on both a rich history of tradition and forward-looking communal and musical values. From Drew Barrymore's birthday party to the Steinway Club of Puerto Rico, Kylemore Abbey to the White House, Doox has sung in venues across the world, entertaining audiences with heartfelt singing and tongue-in-cheek humor.

name: DOWN Magazine
category: Cultural, LGBTQ, Publication, AACC Affiliate Org, AfAm Affiliate Org, NACC Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: The purpose of this organization is to amplify the diverse voices and interests of students of color at Yale, and to provide a safe space for those students to be their full selves. DOWN was born because of a dearth of excellent journalism covering the topics that matter to students of color at Yale. Our goal is primarily to provide that coverage. Our secondary goal is to provide a supportive space for students of color to challenge each other to become better writers, and to encourage and train new writers to help them find their voice. We achieve this goal through frequent writing workshops led by people like Mark Oppenheimer, Director of the Yale Journalism Initiative and various faculty members of the English Department at Yale.

name: Dr. Tschudi's Research Ethics and Responsibility EPH 600
mission: This course seeks to introduce major concepts in the ethical conduct of research and some of the personal and professional issues that researchers encounter in their work. Sessions are run in a seminar/discussion format. Prerequisite: doctoral student or postdoctoral status only.

name: Duke Environmental Law and Policy Clinic
Dwight Hall at Yale - Center for Public Service and Social Justice
mission:
At Dwight Hall, we believe in change. We believe that change is possible and worth fighting for. And in these uncertain times, we believe change has never been more important. That is why we do everything we can to make social change a reality, and why we are dedicated to shaping those who will one day shape the world.
Founded by undergraduates in 1886, Dwight Hall at Yale is an independent, social-profit organization whose mission is to nurture and inspire students as leaders of social change and to advance justice and service in New Haven and around the world. As the Center for Public Service and Social Justice, Dwight Hall's values include a commitment to the common good, compassion, diversity, growth and learning, partnership, critical reflection, and student initiative.

name: Dwight Hall Socially Responsible Investment Fund
mission:
By helping to manage the Dwight Hall endowment, we employ a modern approach to socially responsible investing (SRI) that aims to have a positive environmental and social impact while outperforming standard investment benchmarks. It is our hope that our portfolio will contribute to the success of Dwight Hall, inspire the creation of similar funds at other colleges, and make SRI both accessible and exciting to college students.
For more, visit bit.ly/dhsri-interest.

name: Global Surgery Interest Group
mission:
For a very long time, surgery was not included in the discussion of how healthcare could be improved worldwide, especially in the most remote corners of the earth. Only recently has surgery been brought to the table, being called the "forgotten step-child" of global health by Paul Farmer and many others. At the very core, global surgery is "a field that aims to improve health and health equity for all who are affected by surgical conditions or have a need for surgical care, with a particular focus on underserved populations in countries of all income levels, as well as populations in crisis, such as those experiencing conflict, displacement, and disaster." Important to this effort is all aspects of surgery, including anesthesia, OB/Gyn, and nursing.

Currently, 5 billion people around the world do not have adequate access to basic surgical care. Worse yet, the disparity in surgical care is stark, with the poorest 30% of the world receives only 3-6% of operations, whereas the richest 30% receives almost 75%. 17 million people die and 77 million DALYS are lost each year because of this, greater than HIV/AIDS, malaria, and TB combined. Our global economy could lose 21 trillion dollars between 2015 and 2030, with 12.3 trillion lost by low- and middle-income countries, so the lack of surgical care worldwide is also a significant detriment to the progress of humanity. 2.2 million more surgeons, anesthetists, and OB/Gyns (SAOs) and an investment of $350 billion dollars is needed to prevent this from happening, with a goal to raise the operative volume of countries to 5,000 per 100,000 population, meaning an increase of 143 million more surgical procedures per year. It can be easy to get lost in the numbers, but ultimately, health is a human right, and no one should have to live with a condition that would have been treated had they been born somewhere else.

So the bigger question becomes how we address this need for surgical care. In the past, this has almost exclusively involved efforts such as week-long surgical missions and the provision of money/resources in order to acutely work on the problem. However, the field has evolved with the creation of the Lancet Commission on Global Surgery, which called for a more in-depth analysis. Their major report from spring 2015 outlined an approach through investigation, innovation, and implementation, pointing out that research, technology, and capacity-building efforts were necessary to advance the field. In addition, they did a thorough economic analysis which showed that upscaling the number of surgeons and operations alone will not work - an economic approach that helps decrease catastrophic health expenditure for patients and their families is necessary. As the Lancet Commission encompasses almost 110 different countries, efforts have now been set on working at the highest level - with governments, health ministers, and financial officers - to enact changes in policy and infrastructure for whole countries to improve people's access to surgical care.

Ultimately, whether you are interested in surgery/anesthesia/OBGyn, global/public health, economics/finance, policy, technology/engineering, education/empowerment, statistics/research, or any combination of these, you have a very significant contribution to make to this growing field. And no matter how young or old you are, no matter how little or how much you can contribute, your involvement in global surgery is incredibly necessary and valuable.
*Reference: Meara, J, Leather A, Hagander L, et al. Global surgery 2030: Evidence and solutions for achieving health, welfare, and economic development. Lancet. 2015;386:569-624.

name: Dwight Hall's First-Years in Support of New Haven
mission: Initiated in 2015, First-Years in Support of New Haven is an academic-year program for Yale College first-years to sustainably connect and consciously engage with the vibrant New Haven community. Our aim is to learn from the leadership and experience of community partners who dedicate their professional and personal lives to our shared city. We strive to foster open conversations about the changing New Haven/Yale relationship and engage in sustainable service that will continue throughout each student's time in New Haven.

name: Dzana Dance
category: Cultural, Performance: Dance, AfAm Affiliate Org
mission: Dzana exists as a means for different African cultures to interact and be showcased to the greater Yale community through dance.

name: Ecosystem Management and Conservation Learning Community
mission: Students engaged with this LC build a knowledge base and develop skills they can use to help steward and conserve ecosystems, ensuring that human and nonhuman species can coexist across landscapes.

name: Ecuatorianos y Amigos Unidos
mission: Founded by sisters Shannon and Leslie Guerra during the pandemic, Ecuatorianos y Amigos Unidos is an undergraduate organization aiming to promote Ecuadorian culture on campus. The club unites Ecuadorian and Ecuadorian American students, as well as those interested in Ecuadorian culture. It offers a warm community and regular opportunities to discuss traditional cuisine, music, and social and environmental causes unique to Ecuador. Join us for movie nights, speaker events, intellectual debates, art and cooking experiences, and many more!

name: EJAY SIG
mission: Environmental Justice at Yale (EJAY) is committed to creating a space for students to advocate for and discuss issues of environmental justice at any scale. We are a collaborative group that works to push Yale, the School of the Environment, and our community to be more inclusive and equitable by addressing issues of EJ.

name: Eli Whitney Student Society
mission: The Eli Whitney Student Society (EWSS) consists of the Eli Whitney students at Yale and aims to serve their collective academic and social interests as non-traditional undergraduates.

name: Elm Campus Partners - Apartments for Yale Students & Affiliates
mission: To strengthen communities through our management of inviting public and private spaces, our exceptional customer service, and our financial stewardship.

name: Elm City Echo
mission: The Elm City Echo aims to promote awareness of homelessness and displacement by giving contributors a community-oriented platform to amplify their voices and experiences. The Echo empowers individuals through the process of sharing while centralizing creators' voices. Since 2011, student volunteers have worked with individuals experiencing extreme poverty and homelessness to record and publish the prose, poetry, and artwork. Each collaboration begins with volunteers visiting one of our community partners (Columbus House or Fellowship Place) to facilitate the storytelling process. Once a semester, we publish the pieces in a literary magazine that is freely distributed around New Haven.

name: European Studies Council
mission: The European Studies Council at the MacMillan Center promotes innovative research on Europe's past and present in the context of regional and global interactions. The Council collaborates with schools and departments throughout Yale to support faculty, students, and visiting scholars by sharing their interdisciplinary expertise on European affairs with the broader public. The Council aims to foster a wider understanding of Europe as both a place and an idea, reflecting the evolving nature of the region and its network of connections throughout the world.

name: ELP Summer Academic Language Program
mission:
Advanced language proficiency is not easy to come by, but is essential for success at Yale. It is a prerequisite for being given a Teaching Fellowship (usually beginning in the second year). It is also an essential part of being an active scholar and researcher in one's field, and for being successful in the job market upon graduation. It also takes time; our program is designed to give students an early start on this process.
The Yale Summer Academic Language Program has been specially designed to help incoming PhD students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. The program seeks to prepare incoming students for life in the US, New Haven, and Yale. The program is an intensive one, with a wide range of activities, including classes, conversation sessions with senior graduate students, and directed self-study modules.

name: Emerging Biomedical Scholars at Yale
mission:
The Yale School of Medicine has a mission to "Educate and inspire scholars and future leaders who will advance the practice of medicine and the biomedical sciences." These scholars pursuing advances in the biomedical sciences are spread across departments at the School of Medicine, the School of Arts and Sciences, and Yale-New Haven Hospital. They span a range of professional levels, including medical and graduate students, medical residents and post-docs, early-career investigators, and tenured professors. There are few mechanisms to unite this community of scholars and to bridge the horizontal boundaries of discipline and the vertical boundaries of professional hierarchy. Emerging Biomedical Scholars at Yale aims to provide a unique, unifying service to this broad community. Its mission is to:
1) Serve as a hub to foster professional and social interactions across departments and stages of professional development, in order to facilitate scientific synergies and exploration and professional mentorship.
2) Serve as a central clearinghouse of useful information and resources for a wide range of biomedical scientists, including: core facilities and technical expertise, training in skills such as grant and fellowship writing, other opportunities for education and career development, and means to help promote sustainable work/life balance.

name: Emerging Majority Students Association
mission: The Emerging Majority Students Association (EMSA) is committed to creating and fostering a sense of community among underrepresented students and students interested in the promotion of diversity and inclusion at YSPH. Our three-fold mission is to: 1) serve as a platform for voicing the concerns and interests of minority students at YSPH, 2) promote a multicultural, professional, and academic environment that enables us to address the health issues of minorities in the field of public health with an emphasis on the New Haven community, and 3) collaborate with admissions toward raising the level of underrepresented minority/underrepresented student recruitment, admission, and retention at YSPH.

name: Energy and the Environment Learning Community
mission: Students engaging with this LC examine issues related to energy systems and technologies, policies, and economics — helping them to build a knowledge base they can use to assess the problems posed by both traditional and emerging alternative energy sources.

name: Energy SIG
mission:
The Yale School of the Environment Energy Student Interest Group works on a variety of fronts to increase opportunities and knowledge of the energy sector at Yale. Our activities include hosting guest speakers, running workshops, organizing field trips, and providing networking opportunities for students focused on the nexus between energy and the environment. In addition, we work closely alongside faculty to expand the number of energy-focused course offerings at YSE and to bring in experienced industry professionals as guest lecturers.
Some of our past events include a visit from Jeff Semancik, Director of Radiation at DEEP, to talk about nuclear; a series of chats with Ørsted on wind; and a visit to Yale's power plant.

name: English Language Program
mission: The English Language Program, part of Yale's commitment to internationalization, supports academic communication and the cultural and professional development of the Yale international community. Offering a program centered on assessment of needs, advising, instruction, and consulting, it draws on the expertise of its instructors and staff, as well as a network of English language resources across Yale.

name: Environmental Data Science at Yale (EDSY) SIG
mission: EDSY is a student-led organization passionate about GIS, remote sensing, AI, and conservation tech.

name: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
Environmental Education Collaborative
mission: Established in April of 2019, EECO is Yale's first student organization dedicated to inspiring a generation of environmentally-conscious individuals by teaching K-12 students in New Haven. EECO builds strong relationships with local schools and community organizations by developing and teaching place-based curriculum, as well as by leading field trips in New Haven and implementing sustained environmental education projects to reinforce students' learning in the classroom.

name: Environmental Leadership and Training Initiative
mission: We train and support people from all sectors and backgrounds to restore and conserve tropical forest landscapes using strategies that support biodiversity and livelihoods.

name: Environmental Policy Analysis Learning Community
mission: This LC helps students gain a deeper understanding of the foundations and methods of policy analysis, including how to evaluate their strengths and weaknesses and how to apply these frameworks to a broad range of environmental and resource management issues.

name: Environmentalists of Color Collective
category: Advocacy/Policy, Social, Sports/Outdoors, Cultural: Mixed Race, Special Interest
mission: The Environmentalists of Color Collective aims to build community among students of color who share an interest in the Earth, the outdoors, and environmental justice issues. By centering and celebrating the voices of environmentalists of color, we seek to challenge the historical and ongoing marginalization of people of color within environmental movements. We engage in this work primarily by providing an affinity space, organizing outdoor trips, hosting creative projects and speaker events, and engaging in advocacy to reimagine contemporary environmentalism as a more inclusive effort for a safe and sustainable world.

name: Equity in the Job Search - an annual event for Graduate students, Postdocs and the Yale Community
mission: The Equity in the Job Search Symposium is an annual symposium that provides practical, hands-on workshops to assist graduate students and postdocs at all stages of the STEM job search. We integrate this career advice with data-driven discussions of gender bias to expand the conversation of gender bias to a larger population. The guiding principle behind the symposium is to overcome bias for all. We aim to impart to our participants the idea that everyone benefits from more inclusivity.

name: European Horizons
mission: The Yale Chapter will hold weekly meetings with members chosen from the Yale student body. These meetings will include think tank activities such as discussing possible policies that European governments or the European Union could implement in response to current events and crises. We will provide students with a platform to publish work pertaining to the European Union and European politics. The Yale Chapter will be responsible for organizing the European Horizons regional conference at Yale this year. This organization will hold speaker events open to the public, and will endeavor to include other like-minded organizations to bring the experts in the European field together. Through these series of activities we aim to have real impact on the state of the European Union and produce material that will be published in the European Horizons Journal, and other publications.

name: Federalist Party, The
mission: We the members of the Federalist Party, have banded together to resist the errors of the age and to promote among ourselves the tempering of taste, the ennoblement of custom, the correction of judgment, the cultivation of virtue, and the perfection of friendship.

name: Fellowships and Funding
mission:
Education at Yale takes place inside classroom, library, laboratory, and far beyond. Yale and outside funding options can help make it possible to pursue something amazing which you might not be able to do otherwise. Find support for research, study abroad, public service, unpaid internships, and self-designed projects, in New Haven and around the globe. Postgraduate fellowships support independent projects, graduate study, and much more.
→ funding.yale.edu

name: FGLI Pre-Health Community
mission: To provide support and various opportunties for first-generation, low income students interested in any aspects of the health field (pre-medicine, pre-dental, pre-vet, nursing, etc). We host panels with guests, info sessions, and MCAT study sessions.

name: Film and Fine Foods Club
mission: The mission of the Film and Fine Foods Club is to build a strong, enthusiastic community of Yale undergraduates who meet regularly and bond through group activities like cooking, baking, and film.

name: Financial Literacy
mission:
Demystifying the world of money management — from credit cards to budgets to taxes, being a student comes with its own set of financial hurdles.
Explore and learn how to take ownership of your financial life.
finlit.yale.edu

name: Fine Arts Student Interest Group
mission: Our mission is to provide students with opportunities to interact with the art around them, to create spaces where they can grow as artists, and to build a creative community

name: FIRST at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: FIRST at Yale serves as a community of students dedicated to supporting FIRST. For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) is an international robotics competition for K-12 students that aims to teach professionalism and cooperative competition through hands-on engineering. Yale is home to hundreds of FIRST alumni, and the FIRST at Yale organization was founded in 2017 to give these alumni a home to continue FIRST's mission as well as welcoming new members to the FIRST community. FIRST at Yale members help mentor teams, provide support and a professional network, volunteer at competitions, and more.

name: First Generation Professionals
mission: First Generation Professionals at Yale Law ("FGP") seeks to provide a safe and welcoming space for Yale Law School students who are the first in their families to pursue a professional degree - primarily serving those who come from lower-income and working class backgrounds - to discuss and assist each other with their concerns as they navigate the environment of Yale Law School. We advocate for policies that better meet the needs of our members and seek to foster a broader conversation about class at the Yale Law School. Finally, FGP acknowledges and embraces our membership's diversity and differences in all forms, including those of age, color, disability, ethnicity, gender identity or expression, geographic or national origin, political ideology, race, religion, sexual orientation, and veteran status.

name: First Love Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: FLY is established to regularly gather students for the purpose of teaching the Word of God and fostering Christian fellowships and training leaders while observing the laws of the land. The purpose of this fellowship is to present the Gospel of Jesus Christ to this generation. We are committed to spreading the love of Christ to this generation, which is effectively communicated in the name of the organization. We seek to make the love of Christ known who is our first love.

name: First-Year Outdoor Orientation Trips
mission:
Freshman Outdoor Orientation Trips (FOOT) is an orientation program of backpacking trips for entering Yale freshmen led by two upper class leaders.  Students hike along trails to enjoy the views, cook simple meals, and set up tarps under the stars.  Freshmen hear about college life first-hand from older students.  However, much more is accomplished—students learn skills that have immediate practical use, they are challenged physically to reach goals and mentally to endure hardships, and learn they can accomplish more than they thought. Students come together and form a tight bond of lasting friendships, and they create a close group that supports them during the oncoming years.
Goals of the leaders are to create an atmosphere of trust and inclusiveness, and to ensure the safety and well being of each freshman.  It is the mission of FOOT for students get in touch with themselves and the great outdoors in the wonderful wilderness of the Northeast.  In addition to the focus on freshmen, FOOT is a proven leadership training program for its leaders.  After undergoing our leader training sessions and leading trips, FOOT Leaders can apply the skills they have learned to almost any situation or career choice that involves problem solving, critical thinking and empathy for others.

name: Food SIG
mission: Sustainable Food & Agriculture SIG aims to educate the YSE and larger Yale student body on the environmental issues and challenges of agriculture, and to highlight the agricultural ecosystem as an important component of ecosystem studies and management. It is also our goal to help students, staff, and faculty make the connection between the academic and the personal facets of agriculture, by illustrating how and where the food they eat is produced. The group works actively with local farmers and producers, as well as international agricultural and food system issues.

name: For Bright College Years
mission:
#ForBrightCollegeYears is a collaboration between the Yale College Office of Development, Yale Alumni Fund, and Yale Alumni Association to engage current undergraduates in the impact of philanthropy and alumni connections on campus while stewarding lifelong relationships with the University.
From the moment they arrive at Yale, all students experience the support of a community of donors, alumni, and administrators. This community stretches back for generations and provides the resources current Yalies need to shape the College's present and future.
Through outreach that is both entertaining and educational, #ForBrightCollegeYears introduces the vitality of alumni and donor support while inviting students to leave their mark on Yale long after they graduate.

name: Forestry Club (FC)
mission: Forestry Club, as the hub of student-led community building at the Yale School of the Environment, creates memorable experiences that embody our core principles of community, inclusivity, sustainability, and leadership.

name: Forestry Learning Community
mission: Building on over a century of leadership in forestry and land conservation, this LC helps students gain the knowledge base they need to work collaboratively across environmental disciplines to manage forests in a way that respects the land and one another.

name: French Department - Graduate Program and DGS
fSTS@Yale: An Undergraduate Collective
mission: fSTS@Yale envisions practical and creative interventions into the landscape of STEM at Yale by creating a collective of students interested in a more inclusive, diverse, and justice-oriented way of engaging in science and technology studies (STS). Operating as a resource pool for those interested in STS (or frustrated by its limitations), fSTS@Yale supports collaboration and connection across disciplines.

name: FUSE Magazine
mission: At its core, Fuse Magazine was founded with the intention of celebration and collaboration: to celebrate all that is creative, artistic, and cultural in Yale and New Haven. We spotlight artists regardless of medium, connecting student designers, artists, writers, and photographers to work together.  We aim to fill a niche in the cultural and creative intersection at Yale, to amplify new voices and broaden ideas of what is considered art, culture, and fashion. Our contributors will draw inspiration from the culture & history around us, recognizing the inspiration it offers. [Still, we are mindful that relationships to place are various, sacred, delicate, and sometimes fraught.]  This city and institution are full of opportunities to explore cultural, historical, artistic, and journalistic topics. With that, you will find a broad scope of topics in FUSE. With spreads celebrating everything from ballet to barber shops, Issue 1 is a true celebration of our community's creative potential. We hope that going forward, Fuse is able to serve as a starting point for students to explore parts of Yale and New Haven unfamiliar to them.  We hope that Fuse can become a platform of exciting, bold, culturally-minded visual and written work.

name: GCRE | Graduate Conference in Religion and Ecology
mission: Hosted at Yale University, the Graduate Conference in Religion and Ecology reflects a desire to provide a space for students to engage in dynamic, interdisciplinary conversations across curricular boundaries, and strives to connect ethos with ethics, and ethics to applicable practicality.

name: Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition
mission: The Gilder Lehrman Center for the Study of Slavery, Resistance, and Abolition is part of the Whitney and Betty MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies at Yale University. Since its founding in 1998, the Gilder Lehrman Center has been dedicated to the investigation and dissemination of knowledge concerning slavery and its legacies across all borders and all time, from the distant past through the present day. The Center fosters improved understandings of the role of slavery, anti-slavery, and the lasting harms of slavery in the functioning of the modern world. Through fellowships, workshops, public programs, and digital resources, the Gilder Lehrman Center supports scholarship, public history, and public education.

name: Girls on the Run
mission:
We see a gap in school systems nationwide in the way that girls are taught about their bodies. By teaching young girls to appreciate their bodies for the power and strength of which they are capable rather than what they look like, we hope to create a foundation for a lifetime of positive body image, high self-esteem, healthy relationships, as well as a love of running.
We also hope that this organization will help break down some of the "bubble" between Yale and New Haven by promoting an extracurricular activity that goes beyond academics and partners with young girls in New Haven as positive female role models.

name: Gruber Fellows Student Group
mission: Group for GSAS Gruber fellows to connect, share, socialize and host programs of interest.

name: Good Life Center
mission: Our mission is two-fold: to empower students with evidence-based skills for fostering mental, physical, social, and emotional well-being, and to cultivate a campus culture that promotes wellness as a fundamental, accessible human right. We all deserve to be, feel, and do well at Yale.

name: Graduate and Professional Affiliate Program with the Residential Colleges
mission: To support undergraduates in their academic and professional pursuits and to connect graduate students from across the university within a vibrant college community.

name: Graduate and Professional Student Senate (GPSS)
Graduate Student Assembly
mission: The Graduate Student Assembly is an elected body of Yale students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. The Assembly's goals are to identify the needs and concerns of graduate students, consider possible solutions, and present these to the Dean and other administrators. We also discuss, propose, and advise on possible changes to Graduate School policy proposed by the administration. The assembly provides a means for communication and deliberation both among graduate students and between graduate students and other members of the Yale community.

name: Graduate Student Disability Alliance
mission: The Graduate Student Disability Alliance (GSDA) is an affinity group for graduate and professional students who are situated within the disability umbrella. The primary function of the Graduate Student Disability Alliance is to create a sense of community among graduate students with disabilities, advocate for members of our community, foster a sense of belonging on campus, and support our members while they navigate graduate school and beyond.

name: GREEN
mission:
The purpose of this club shall be:
1. To reduce the environmental impact associated with a school campus.
2. To engage and mobilize people around conscious living and environmental issues at Yale and in the New Haven area.
3. To use school campuses as a palette for modeling real-life solutions to sustainability challenges.

name: Green Chemistry SIG
mission: The Green Chemistry SIG aims to provide greater access to and engagement with the field of green chemistry.

name: Green Haven Prison Project
mission: The Green Haven Prison Project meets with a group of prisoners dedicated to self-improvement at the Green Haven Correctional Facility. Every other week we have a shared seminar with the prisoners discussing current issue of political or personal interest.

name: Greenhouse Botanical Club
mission: The Greenhouse Botanical Club aims to provide a platform for members of Yale University to learn plant science and also have fun. Members will have the chance to learn plant propagation techniques and learn about plant collections at Marsh Botanical Garden. Moreover, we hope to influence undergraduate students to get involved in plant science in the future.

name: GSAS Admitted Students  - Yale Graduate School of Arts & Sciences
mission: Welcome to this group for students who have been admitted to Yale Graduate School, OR who have accepted the offer of admission, to begin studies in Fall 2021. In this group you can find information on life at Yale GSAS and New Haven, attend virtual events, ask questions, and meet other prospective students (looking for house-mates, maybe?). We will share info about events and resources to prospective and new students here. Post your questions on the feed or email us at gsas.newstudents@yale.edu

name: GSAS Dept. Registrars and DGS Assistants Group
GSAS Graduate Professional Experience (GPE) Fellowship
mission: The GSAS Professional Experience (GPE) Fellowship is an exciting new initiative by the Yale Graduate School of Arts and Sciences that offers Ph.D. students the opportunity to work on meaningful projects in administrative offices across the university. This program is designed to expand opportunities for doctoral students to strengthen their professional skill set and broaden their career exposure by working with experienced administrators outside of their academic programs. In turn, by hosting a fellow, offices across Yale can take advantage of the diverse array of skills that Ph.D. students offer to advance their programming and projects.

name: GSAS Health & Safety Team - COVID Info & Forms for GSAS Students
mission: The GSAS Health and Safety Team and the School Heakt & Safety Leaders (HSL) are here to give you Info and resources to keep safe and healthy at Yale  and in greater New Haven. Sharing and amplifying info and policies from Yale Health and Safety Guidelines and promoting healthy practices is our main goal during the current COVID-19 pandemic.

name: GSAS Peer Orientation Mentors (POM) - Mentor Leadership Group
GSAS Professional Development
category: Academic, Administrative, Advocacy/Policy, Entrepreneurial/Business, Health/Wellness, International Affairs, Leadership, Media/Technology, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Pre-Professional, Professional, Publication, Religious/Spiritual, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering, Speech/Debate, Student Government, Special Interest, OISS Affiliate Org, International

name: Japanese Association of Students and Scholars at Yale
mission: The purpose of Japanese Association for Students and Scholars at Yale (JASY) is to connect all Japanese and Japan-affiliated people on campus. Our group consists of people from academia, government, industry, or non-profit organizations, providing an opportunity to a network with different backgrounds.

name: Korean Graduate Student Association at Yale
mission:
Korean Graduate Student Association at Yale is an active organization on campus with around 150-200 members. Our purpose is to help Korean and Korea-interested graduate students navigate opportunities and communities around campus.
The purpose of the organization is to enhance the network and the academic and vocational cooperation among the Korean graduate students at Yale, and to provide social, cultural and educational functions for Korean graduate students as well as the general student body at Yale. We also serve as as a liaison among Korean Associations in the New England region and we seek to promote the network with other associations at the university and the community.

name: Kpop Dance Society at Yale - a graduate student organization
mission: KDSY is a Kpop dance society at Yale. We hope to encourage interaction and collaboration with other dance groups on campus and make KDSY a reflection of Yale's diverse and creative environment. Also, allowing students of all cultural and dance backgrounds to participate in bringing the variety, skill, and vibrancy of Korean dance to the stage.

name: Ludi et Veritas - Board Game Club  for Yale students and affiliates
mission: Ludi et Veritas is a Yale board gaming club. Our goal is to bring people together to play board games. We meet regularly (usually weekly) to play and teach board games that promote the social interaction, intellectual stimulation, and just plain fun that comes out of unplugging from our busy lives. Ludi et Veritas is committed to make board games inclusive to all members of the Yale community. We have members that are undergraduates, graduate/professional students, postdocs, and Yale staff. We welcome gamers of all levels and tastes. We have some games available at all times at the Office of International Students and Scholars (OISS) and we generally bring different types of games for all levels and people to teach them. But please, bring your own games if you want. You may find others that want to play them.

name: New Haven Science Fair Program - for Graduate Students
mission:
The goal of the New Haven Science Fair Program is to work with students and teachers from New Haven Pre-K through Grade 12 classrooms, to help them carry out investigative hands-on science fair projects in order to promote skills in critical thinking, the scientific process, and science communication.
The program now engages about half of the population of the New Haven Public School system (over 8,000 students) and almost all of its schools (43 schools), utilizing more than 200 volunteers for mentors and judges each year.

name: Open Labs at Yale - a Graduate Student Organization
mission: Open Labs organizes science outreach events for K-12 students in the New Haven area. We coordinate multiple forms of outreach including hands-on science demonstrations, science talks, and digital content!

name: oSTEM.Grad
mission: oSTEM is a dedicated community of LGBTQ STEM students interested in building a community on campus and fostering opportunities for leadership and professional development.

name: PROSPER: Peers for Resilience, Openness, Support, Perspective, Empowerment and Relationships: A Graduate and Professional Student-Run Organization
mission: PROSPER (Peers for Resilience, Openness, Support, Perspective, Empowerment and Relationships) is a Graduate and Professional (G&P) student-run organization dedicated to fostering honest, moderated, educational and peer-supportive spaces to help inspire, connect and empower students to rise to the challenges of G&P education.

name: Transitions - Graduate Student First Year Experience
Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Working Group and Colloquium
mission: The Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Working Group invites faculty to share their projects – often works-in-progress or recent publications – with graduate students and faculty on Mondays, from 5:30-7:00 PM, WLH 309, with a light dinner served. Works typically are pre-circulated one week in advance and then the guest offers framing remarks prior to an open discussion of the piece.

name: Yale Graduate Student Debate Association
mission: The Yale Graduate Student Debate Association is now open! Join our community of debaters from across Yale for our biweekly debates on critical issues and monthly speaker training workshops. If you've ever wanted to debate or have years of debating experience this is the group for you. See you at our next event!

name: Yale Office of Career Strategy (OCS) - GSAS & Postdocs
Guild of Bookmakers
mission: The purpose of the Guild of Bookmakers is to make the experience of bookbinding available to everyone on campus, to rekindle interest in bookbinding and the book arts, and to bring together people who share a love of bookbinding.

name: Hear Your Song
mission: Hear Your Song is dedicated to giving children the opportunity to express themselves freely and have their voice amplified by song in clinical settings where they otherwise may not have the option for musical self-expression.

name: Guild of Carillonneurs
mission: The purpose of the Guild shall be to maintain a regular ringing schedule of the Yale Memorial Carillon in Harkness Tower during the academic year; to further the musical education of its members by, among other things, meeting regularly as a group to perform for each other and visiting other carillons at least once a year; to teach and train underclassmen in the art of carillon-playing during the annual Heel and to elect new members into the Guild after auditions at the end of Heel; to organize a carillon concert series each summer; to perform at official functions of the University; to maintain and further good relations with carillonneurs at other carillons around the world, the Guild of Carillonneurs in North America (GCNA), and the national carillon schools in Europe; to maintain and enlarge the library of music sheets and books and literature on campanology; and, to encourage general interest in the bells and the art of carillon-playing at the University and in New Haven.

name: Hanppuri
mission: Hanppuri is an organization meant to provide a sense of community for the Korean international students at Yale. With ever-increasing numbers of international Koreans coming each year, it is important that we provide a community where they can find a safe haven and somewhere to escape from some of the hard cultural transitions they may have had to make.

name: HAPPY (Hypertension Awareness and Prevention Program at Yale)
mission: HAPPY is a Yale University student organization committed to providing regular hypertension screening services, linking hypertensive patients with available care, and eliminating barriers to follow-up care for chronic hypertension, for the low-income and homeless populations around New Haven, CT. We engage student volunteers and leaders in active volunteerism, educational outreach, research, publications, fundraising, and other innovative projects to achieve highest quality of our services and maximize our service impact. We envision creating a successful model at Yale and New Haven and replication our model of success in other universities across the country by establishing a national non-profit organization.

name: HAVEN Free Clinic
mission:
The HAVEN Free Clinic is a student-run primary care clinic that partners with Yale University to provide the New Haven community access to comprehensive, high-quality health care free of charge. Our model is unique because we include members across various disciplines in health care, including medicine, nursing, physician's associate programs, and public health.
We serve as a sustainable free clinic that provides uninsured adults in New Haven with primary care, wellness education, and assistance in securing health care while simultaneously educating health professional students at Yale about patient care and community health.

name: HAVEN Medical-Legal Partnership
mission: The Haven MLP is a partnership with HAVEN, a free clinic operated by Yale medical students every Saturday for uninsured patients, the great majority of whom are also undocumented immigrants. Law student volunteers work onsite at the clinic and meet directly with patients to conduct legal screening and identify issues that should be referred to NHLAA for possible legal representation. Common legal issues include immigration, wage theft, landlord/tenant concerns, and domestic violence. A training session is conducted at the beginning of each semester for interested students who can then sign up for individual shifts.

name: Health and Education Advocates for Refugees
mission: Our organization's main mission is to provide accessible and comprehensible pamphlets and/or brochures on physical and mental health necessities, targeting refugee populations in New Haven. Our organization also hopes to raise awareness on the mental and physical health of refugees on Yale's campus. The topics that will be discussed on these pamphlets and/or brochures include, but are not limited to, dental hygiene, women's hygiene, nutrition, and disease prevention.

name: Health Equity Thread
mission: The Health Equity Thread (HET) is a four-year medical curriculum thread designed to equip students with knowledge and skills needed to understand and respond to the challenges of assuring a diverse, equitable, and inclusive healthcare system for patients and communities. Our mission is to train the next generation of physicians to surmount structural barriers to high-quality health care for all.

name: Health Equity Thread
category: Academic, Cultural, LGBTQ, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Pre-Professional
mission: This group will be used to connect to MD students. MD students can use this group to reserve a slot during our weekly Office Hours. The group will also be used to advertise HET events.

name: Health Professionals Recruitment and Exposure Program
Public School Graduates
mission:
The mission of this organization is to create a space for graduates
of public institutions of higher education to network, share
experiences, and combat the imposter syndrome that often attends
being a product of public education in an incredibly elite and, at
times elitist, institution.

name: Helicon - The Yale Undergraduate Journal of Classics
mission: Helicon: The Yale Undergraduate Journal of Classics is a literary magazine published every semester and widely distributed throughout the Yale community. It seeks to foster scholarship in the Classics by providing undergraduate students with a forum to print their writings. Published in a digital format, the journal provides accessible content in order to bridge perceived gaps between Classics and contemporary discussions. We accept submissions from undergraduate students around the world, aiming to establish a network of support and a sense of community among undergraduate, graduate students, and faculty in the Classics.

name: Hellenic Society
mission: A. To bring together the Greeks of Yale University with the purpose of facilitating homogenous relationships, upholding Greek traditions, and formulating a support group that will help native Greeks feel more at home in their new country of habitation. B. To up-date members of the Hellenic Society, members of Yale University, and members of New Haven on Greek cultural and political events. C. To work with other Hellenic Societies of American academic institutions and to bond with the Greek community of New Haven. D. To maintain direct connection with alumni members of the Society in order for the alumni to have a vivid remembrance of their college years and to establish links among older and current members.

name: Hong Kong Students Association
mission: The Hong Kong Students Association (HKSA) is a home away from home for students with ties to Hong Kong. We are a community group for those born and bred in Hong Kong, third culture kids who lived in Hong Kong at a certain point in their lives, individuals whose families emigrated from Hong Kong, and everyone in between. We aim to bring people together through shared cultural experiences, build community, and embrace all the various interpretations of what it means to be a Hong Konger.

name: Hult Prize at Yale
category: Advocacy/Policy, Entrepreneurial/Business, Food/Culinary, Funding, Health/Wellness, International Affairs, Leadership, Media/Technology, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Professional, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering, Social, Special Interest, International
mission:
The Hult Prize is a social impact-oriented entrepreneurship program, and there's an opportunity for students to participate in the Hult Prize at Yale on-campus competition! The competition, which will occur near mid-December, will allow students to compete in teams of 3-4 in pitching a startup idea for the challenge of the year.
If they are the selected winners of the On-Campus competition, they will move on to a Regional competition and, potentially, the final Hult Prize competitions where the winning team & idea wins $1,000,000 to build (or continue building) their startup.
Additionally, they will receive mentorship from business leaders and entrepreneurs within the United Nations Foundation, the Hult Prize Foundation, and the Clinton Global Initiative. The On-Campus competition at Yale will send at least one team to Regionals, which will occur around March 2021.

name: Hungarian Association
mission: To bring together the Hungarian community at Yale, and to inspire future applicants from Hungary.

name: Hunger and Homelessness Action Project
mission: The Yale Hunger and Homelessness Action Project (YHHAP) is a student organization using education and action to alleviate housing and food insecurity in New Haven. Not-for-profit, we use our direct service, community involvement, and advocacy efforts to address root causes and to support immediate and long-term solutions for local food and housing deprivation.

name: Immigration Legal Program at the Lutheran Social Services of New York
Implementation Science Group
mission:
The ISG aims to help students with interest in public health and healthcare services to gain a foundation in Implementation Science by exposing them to high quality implementation science research, training, programming/practice, and resources.
At ISG, we aim to bridge the gap between knowledge and practice in public health and healthcare.

name: Medicine and Religion Interest Group
mission: The Medicine and Religion Interest Group fosters dialogue about the interplay between religion and medicine among students and faculty at Yale University and beyond. We collaborate across departments and schools in the research of religion and medicine and translate and disseminate the fruits of research in order to foster mutual understanding and improve patient care.

name: India at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: India at Yale is an undergraduate organization for anyone interested in Indian culture. We aim to bring Yale's Indian community closer by hosting social and cultural events throughout the year. We hope to proliferate interest among the Indian diaspora at Yale by serving as a space for Indians on campus to connect with and share their roots. We are dedicated to enhancing social, academic, and community engagement while celebrating Indian culture.

name: Indigenous Leaders in Public Health
mission: Indigenous Leaders in Public Health (ILPH) is a student-run organization that operates on the values of kinship, compassion, culture, and humility to create a space for Indigenous students working in public health to network, support, and collaborate with one another. ILPH hopes to grow the Indigenous alumni network, facilitate professional development, and inform research and practice that occurs in and/or in regard to Indigenous communities locally and globally.

name: Industrial Ecology and Environmental Management (IEME) SIG
Industrial Ecology and Green Chemistry Learning Community
mission: Industrial ecology and green design are key to addressing many of the sustainability challenges posed by ever-increasing industrial production.In this LC, students study the energy and materials used in industry, and develop strategic approaches to the design, use, and re-use of materials.

name: Ink & Vellum: Undergraduate Architecture Society
mission: As a society, Ink & Vellum supports student activities and events related to the study of architecture and urban studies, particularly for students in these majors. We intend for the society to support the current interests within the major and provide a stronger community through mentorship as well as educational opportunities outside of the Yale curriculum.

name: Institute of Sacred Music
category: Academic, Administrative, Arts: Other, Performance: Other, Performance: Singing
mission:
Welcome to the Yale Institute of Sacred Music—a premier center for the interdisciplinary study of sacred music, worship, and the related arts. Partnering with the Yale School of Music and Yale Divinity School, as well as other academic and professional units at Yale, the ISM prepares its students for careers in church music and other sacred music, pastoral ministry, performance, and scholarship.
The ISM engages musicians, artists, clergy, and scholars from around the world in rigorous training and collaboration, and offers a full calendar of concerts, lectures, exhibitions, and other events.

name: Institute of Sacred Music Student Life
mission:
- Envision, plan, and implement a range of events open to all ISM students to promote friendship, inclusivity, and respect.
- To empower students to imagine the shape and priorities of interdisciplinary community and create experiences to realize that vision for the benefit of the ISM, Yale, and broader New Haven communities.

name: Internal Medicine-Pediatrics Interest Group
mission: To expose YSM students to the field of combined internal medicine-pediatrics through hands-on activities, lunch/dinner talks, and discussions.

name: International Chemical Biology Society - Yale Chapter
mission:
Mission 1: Educate
As a relatively new field, chemical biology has been growing tremendously over the past few years. We aim to make contributions to the further promotion of the chemical biology field, and help scientists within or without this field better understand what the field entails and its potential to contribute to the frontiers of science. ICBS-Yale is dedicated to educating academics about chemical biology, starting locally with the Yale community, and then expanding to the greater New England area, working together with the ICBS-Boston Chapter.

Mission 2: Appreciate
As the chemical biology field starts to gain more appreciation, many academic institutions are looking to expand in this area. However, it has been noticed that graduate and post-doctoral trainees in chemical biology might still be at disadvantage and sometimes overlooked during job hunting due to the lack of robust understanding of this new field. ICBS-Yale will make efforts to garner more respect and appreciation for this discipline, hoping to bring trainees tremendous benefits in their future career development.

Mission 3: Bridge
ICBS-Yale is dedicated to better bridging the siloed worlds of trainees in the biological and biomedical sciences and trainees in chemistry. We aim to foster communication, collaboration, and community between these disparate research areas.

Mission 4: Connect
ICBS-Yale aims to build stronger connections between academia and industry, and thus provide professional resources to chemical biology trainees, as well as to those who conduct scientific research at the interface between chemistry and biological & biomedical sciences. Yale-based biotech startup companies and therapeutic innovation efforts launched by Yale faculties will also be exploited as tremendous resources within the Yale community, which could be more accessible for Yale trainees.

Mission 5: Develop
As a summary of all previously listed missions and purposes, ICBS-Yale is dedicated to the career development of Yale chemical biology trainees, as well as to those who conduct scientific research at the interface between chemistry and biological & biomedical sciences.

name: Natyamandala
mission: NATYA MANDALA is an Indian classical dance awareness group that promotes traditional Indian dance forms through performance, shows, workshop and other events.

name: International Refugee Assistance Project
mission:
The International Refugee Assistance Project (IRAP) organizes law students and lawyers to develop and enforce a set of legal and human rights for refugees and displaced persons. Mobilizing direct legal aid, litigation, and systemic advocacy, IRAP serves the world's most persecuted individuals and empowers the next generation of human rights leaders.
Since its founding in 2008, IRAP has helped resettle over 4200 refugees and their families to 18 different countries and has trained over 2000 law students and lawyers in the process. The Yale Law School chapter is one of IRAP's 30 student chapters across the United States and Canada.

name: International Society of Tropical Foresters (ISTF) SIG
mission:
ISTF is the home for anyone interested in the tropics and also plays host to one of the largest and longest-running student-led conferences at Yale every spring!
Learn more at https://istfconference.events.yale.edu/

name: International Spouses & Partners at Yale
mission: Meet other spouses & partners and learn more about the opportunities and resources available to you at Yale and in New Haven.

name: ISPY Traditional Chinese Painting and Calligraphy
International Students' Organization
mission:
With over 750 members, ISO is Yale's largest cultural organization and is omnipresent
on campus. Our cultural, political, social and inclusion councils organize culinary, artistic and other cultural events; the best parties on campus; debates and panels with global leaders; and
sessions to help students with the logistics of living abroad.
We strive to provide support to the international students at Yale College as well as organize a wide range of great events of interest to the entire Yale community.

name: J Street U
mission: The purpose of J Street U is to educate the Yale community about the current situation of Israelis and Palestinians, to advocate for American political support and involvement in the realization of the two-state solution, and to provide a community for liberal, like-minded students who are committed to a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

name: J. Reuben Clark Law Society
mission: The J. Reuben Clark Law Society serves members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) and all others interested in or affiliated with the LDS faith.

name: Jackson International Military Veterans Club
mission: A new student organization designed to build an international community of military families that offers support, promotes cross-cultural understanding, and helps families navigate the challenges unique to military life. The group prioritizes building strong relationships and fostering inclusivity to help military families thrive during their time at Yale and beyond.

name: Jackson Latin America and the Caribbean
Jackson School Office of Student Affairs
Jane Matilda Bolin
mission: The Jane Matilda Bolin Program at Yale is an academic and cultural enrichment program designed to engage high school  students of African descent based on a similar program at Harvard University. The J.M. Bolin Program provides students with an opportunity to develop study skills and teamwork as they reflect on readings. The program also works to promote African-American studies, college seminar style discussions, and study skills. The program will also expose New Haven students to the work of Yale professors and connect them with Yale students. The program will normally meet on Saturday afternoons at Yale University's campus.

name: Red Hot Poker
mission: Red Hot Poker produces live sketch comedy onstage and video sketches to be published on our website and YouTube channel. We have roughly four live performances a semester.

name: Japanese American Students Union
mission: The purpose of the Japanese American Students Union is to provide a forum on campus for political, social, and cultural conversation for Yale students of Japanese descent and students interested in Japanese culture. To this end, JASU will conduct outreach to the aforementioned students, organize events, and voice the concerns of the Japanese American community to the larger Asian American and University student-body.

name: Jerome N. Frank Legal Services Organization
Jewish Christian Bible Study
mission: Jewish Christian Bible Study is dedicated to fostering interreligious dialogue through Biblical study. We seek to learn from one another and our diverse approaches to a shared text, and hope to build a strong, collaborative relationship between Jewish and Christian communities on campus.

name: Jewish Medical Student Association (Maimonides Society)
mission: Welcome to the Maimonides Society, which is a Jewish Medical Student Association for the Yale School of Medicine. The Maimonides Society aims to welcome and support students by creating a Jewish community and family. Over the course of the year, we hold classes, events, dinners, holiday parties, and philanthropic events. The Maimonides Society supports our members by helping in any way we can including connecting students to clergy, learning opportunities, services, etc on the Yale campus. The Maimonides Society continues to evolve and pursue the current students' passions from medical ethics to Jewish education.

name: Jook Songs
category: Arts: Other, Cultural, Performance: Other, AACC Affiliate Org
mission:
Jook Songs, Yale's Asian American poetry and performance group, seeks to elevate the creative voices of Asian Americans at Yale through writing, workshopping, and performing.
Since our founding in 1999, we have collaborated with artists such as Sally Wen Mao and Princess Nokia, performed at the Asian American Writers' Workshop, hosted open mics for incoming Yale first-years, created youth poetry workshops with Splash at Yale, and more.

name: Journal of Literary Translation
mission: The Journal of Literary Translation (JoLT) publishes English translations of poetry and prose, as well as essays on the theory and practice of translation. A bi-annual magazine, JoLT seeks to showcase the excellent work of translators at Yale, to think critically about translation in a variety of contexts, and to explore metaphors for translation through the physical design of each issue. We also host readings and workshops to promote literary translation in the greater community at Yale.

name: Just Add Water
category: Arts: Other, Performance: Comedy, Performance: Instruments, Performance: Singing
mission: Just Add Water, affectionately known as JAW, aims to provide the magic of musical improv comedy to the Yale Community and beyond during our on-campus shows, off-campus gigs, and semiannual tours around the United States.  What's more, JAW provides an environment for Yale students to explore themselves and the world around them via improv.  These tools have proven invaluable for our members, current and of legend, and explain in part why JAW is considered a second family by its members.

name: Justice at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Yale Undergraduate Pre-Law Association supports and uplifts FGLI students interested in pursuing a legal career. At Yale, many students do not have the privilege of direct access to pre-law resources or relationships, and YUPLA aims to bridge that gap for all students and make law accessible. As a network connecting both students and faculty with an interest in law, YUPLA aims to help students foster community and create their own path to a legal education and career through one-on-one mentorship programs and pre-professional preparation. Unlike other pre-professional clubs, There is no barrier to entrance. YUPLA welcomes all Yale students interested in joining with the goal of crafting a diverse and accessible legal field.

name: Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Sustainability Initiative (JEDSI)
mission:
The Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Sustainability Initiative (JEDSI) seeks to examine the relationship between social inequalities, lived experiences, and environmental outcomes.  To this end, JEDSI currently focuses on eight primary areas of research, teaching, and practice:
Environmental History
Nature, Outdoor Experiences, Attitudes, and Perceptions
Environmental Inequalities, Resilience, and Sustainability
Food and Farming:  Access, Sovereignty, Food Justice
Institutional Diversity, Transparency, and Workforce Dynamics
Diversity Pathway Programming
New Horizons in Conservation Conference
Mentoring and Profiles of Environmental Professionals of Color

name: SAYPH SBS Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for SBS Students

name: Kasama: The Filipino Club at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission:
Our purpose is to engage the Yale community in issues regarding Filipino culture. We achieve this goal by hosting events that raise awareness of Filipino identity, such as cooking events, weekly dinners, mixers, cultural shows, and political discussions.
Kasama is a small club and our name - translated from Tagalog as "together" - embodies our mission to bring together members of the community both Filipino and non-Filipino. Thus Kasama is involved in the Asian American Cultural Center at Yale, The Asian American Students Alliance, and other umbrella organizations in order to embrace both Filipino and pan-Asian identity. We work closely with other groups at Yale to foster a sense of collaboration and inclusivity.

name: Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program
category: Advocacy/Policy, Health/Wellness, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Pre-Professional, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering
mission: KDSAP is a student-run organization targeting college students and aims to provide opportunities for community outreach to raise public awareness and promote early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

name: Korean American Students at Yale
mission: The Korean American Students at Yale (KASY) was established in 1984 by a group of students who wanted to promote the cultural, political, and social interests of the community of Korean Americans at Yale. In the thirty-plus years since its inception, KASY has grown both in size and influence, but still remains dedicated to its founding principles. Known as a vibrant and thriving undergraduate organization, KASY functions as a promoter of cultural awareness, a vehicle for political action, and most importantly, a tightly-knit family.

name: Korean Student Group
mission: The Korean Student Group consists of students at YDS who identify themselves as Korean-American, Korean-Korean, or Korean—, who are also exploring and/or practicing their faith in the North American context. This group encourages students to grow and sustain their identities by means of prayers, worship, and fellowship. Our gatherings provide a safe space for sharing individual experiences of bringing the Korean culture/heritage into both religious and academic settings at YDS and beyond.

name: L'Amuse-Bouche: Yale University's Undergraduate French-Language Journal
mission: Founded in 2007, L'Amuse-Bouche: La revue française de Yale is Yale University's undergraduate French-language journal. L'AB publishes student work — prose, poetry, and essays on French and francophone literature, history, and culture — as well as academic articles by prominent francophone writers, academics, and public figures from across the world.

name: La Casa Cultural Julia de Burgos: The Latino Cultural Center at Yale
mission: Building on a strong campus community, the Latino Cultural Center promotes a sense of unity among Latinx people at Yale. We are committed to providing a comfortable space where our diverse cultural heritage, history and traditions can be celebrated and explored by all Yale University and New Haven community members. In partnership with our resident organizations, La Casa provides opportunities that foster a sense of belonging and pride while supporting the intellectual, personal, leadership and social development of our students.

name: La Comunidad
category: Cultural, Religious/Spiritual, Social, La Casa  Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race, International
mission: La Comunidad, the YDS Latinx/e Student Group, is dedicated to creating spaces for Latinx voices and bodies at YDS to gather and build community of solidarity and support. La Comunidad also seeks to provide resources to promote theological and cultural education for an entire YDS student body preparing for service to the church and the world. La Comunidad hopes to foster comunidad Latina: an open, welcoming place to learn, struggle, and celebrate.

name: La Orquesta Tertulia
category: Cultural, Performance: Instruments, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: La Orquesta Tertulia serves to provide a space for Latin American students and all those who share a passion for salsa music and performing arts! Through musical performance, we aim to foster unity among the student body and the greater New Haven community.

name: LuMin at Yale
mission:
LuMin at Yale is…
a community that honors questions
a gathering of spirit, conversation and justice-seeking
a refuge from academic pressure and deadlines

name: Lutheran Student Organization
mission: Through worship, retreats, prayer, and informal gatherings, the Lutheran Student Organization (LSO) provides fellowship for all students involved in the Lutheran traditions. Functioning within YDS's Lutheran Studies Program, students plan Tuesday evening Vespers in the Nouwen Chapel and intermittently assist with Lutheran chapel services in Marquand. The LSO also sponsors guest speakers and discussion forums for issues pertinent to the YDS community.

name: La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Inc.
category: Cultural, Greek-Letter Organizations, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission:
La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity, Incorporated primarily seeks to take a leadership role in meeting the needs of the Latino community through academic achievement, cultural awareness, community service and promotion of the Latino culture and people.
We strive to become the premier Latino Fraternity in the country. More specifically, we strive to become a nationally recognized Latino fraternal organization comprised of the best and brightest leaders committed to excellence in service and education.
Since its inception in 1982, La Unidad Latina has remained on the vanguard of political and community empowerment by developing influential leaders that strive to exert knowledge and power into its peers in order to attain mutual success. We commit ourselves to academic excellence, leadership development and cultural enlightenment, enhanced by a diverse cognizant membership. La Hermandad strives to preserve and promote an inclusive intellectual environment for its members, in addition to the general community.

name: Latina Women at Yale
category: Cultural, Food/Culinary, Health/Wellness, Leadership, Service/Volunteering, Social, La Casa  Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: Latina Women at Yale strives to create a community and safe space on campus for all Latinas across all intersectional identities. We listen to and learn from one another, as we support each other as Latina women.

name: Latinx Law Students' Association
mission: The Latinx Law Students Association (LLSA) supports Latinx students at YLS primarily by community building, providing professional and academic mentorship, offering opportunities for political engagement on issues confronting the Latinx community, and connecting members with Latinx alumni and practitioners.

name: Law Students for Justice in Palestine
LEDA @ Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: To create a vibrant LEDA family at Yale that embodies LEDA's core values of Excellence, Integrity, Compassion, and Community by supporting members with critical resources for college and professional success.

name: Legal Aid Society - Criminal Appeals Bureau
Legal Aid Society - District of Columbia
Legal Aid Society - Homeless Rights Project
Light and Truth
category: Academic, Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Political, Publication, Religious/Spiritual, Speech/Debate
mission: PROMOTING VIEWPOINTS ON YALE'S CAMPUS, LIGHT & TRUTH IS AN ONLINE STUDENT PUBLICATION THAT PROVIDES THOUGHTFUL AND RIGOROUS ESSAYS, ARTICLES, AND OTHER WORKS IN PHILOSOPHY, POLITICS, AND CULTURE.

name: Living Village Construction
mission: Providing timely updates about the Living Village construction impact for the YDS community.

name: Living Water at Yale – an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Living Water is Yale's first Christian a cappella group. Founded in 1979, Living Water at Yale exists to spread the Gospel, the good news of God's love and desire for relationship with all of humankind fulfilled through Jesus Christ. As a group, we spread the Gospel by sharing our testimonies of God's faithfulness, singing music that tells His story, glorifying Him through our craft, and reflecting His love and truth in our service toward Yale, New Haven, our respective home communities, and each other.

name: Lo Stivale
mission: Lo Stivale is the Italian culture club at Yale. Our mission is to celebrate Italian culture (in the form of food, cinema, games, etc.) through internal events, yet also to promote it through events that are accessible to the Yale public at large.

name: Low Strung
mission: Low Strung provides cellists with the opportunity to explore new kinds of cello playing and perform for audiences on campus and worldwide.

name: Lowenstein Human Rights Project
