mission: The Lowenstein Human Rights Project matches small teams of students with human rights organizations, other public interest NGOs, and governments to work on specific research, writing, and advocacy projects concerning human rights issues.

name: Lux Improvitas, An Undergraduate Ensemble
mission: Lux Improvitas seeks to explore the possibilities and boundaries of improvisation. While the central medium for much of this exploration is the "improvised play" (and its derivatives), every iteration of the Lux Improvitas ensemble should feel encouraged to explore styles of improv beyond this format and to create new forms of its own. We believe in creativity, in change, and in community.

name: Magevet
mission: Magevet's mission is to bring a diverse range of Jewish, Hebrew, and Israeli music to communities around the world.

name: Mahjong Undergraduate Society for Students at Yale
mission: The Mahjong Undergraduate Society for Students at Yale will introduce mahjong to the greater Yale community. We will accomplish this goal by providing meeting spaces, mahjong equipment, and experienced players to both novices and veterans of the game throughout the semester. Further, we aim to enrich the cultural experiences of Yalies, current and future by sharing the customs and traditions that have surrounded mahjong.

name: Maison at Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: MAISON is a fashion and art collective that aims to spearhead creative expression at Yale through outlets including fashion shows, photoshoots, speaker events, and more. We provide a platform where student creatives can showcase their work and connect with one another, other local creatives, and beyond. Our focus is to be a space where all fashion enthusiasts and artists, regardless of experience, can fulfill their artistic vision.

name: Malaysian and Singaporean Association
mission: The Malaysian and Singaporean Association (MASA) supports the interests of Malaysian and Singaporean students, and promotes the culture of both countries at Yale.

name: MAR Cohort Group
mission: Space for MAR current students. Receive news and updates from your year group reps, schedule events together as a program community and connect with other MAR'ers!

name: Mariachi Lux Et Veritas de Yale - A Student Organization
category: Cultural, Performance: Other, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: Mariachi Luz y Verdad de Yale is a Yale undergraduate Traditional Mariachi group for students who celebrate Mexican culture and inspire others to do the same. We beautify our campus with Mexican folklore music and entertainment. In collaboration with Ballet Folklorico Mexicano de Yale, we will showcase performances that bring awareness, love, culture, and representation to the Mexican and Latine communities on campus. It serves all students by contributing to the diverse Yale campus and providing the means for cultural appreciation.

name: Marquand Chapel
category: Administrative, Arts: Other, Arts: Visual Arts, Performance: Other, Performance: Singing, Religious/Spiritual
mission:
Marquand Chapel is at the heart of Yale Divinity School.
Worship is planned and led by students, faculty, and staff of both Yale Divinity School and the Institute of Sacred Music, under the leadership of the Dean of Chapel and a team of staff and students.
Worship in Marquand often draws on a wide variety of inherited Christian traditions, with the worship of many denominations being represented. Beyond that, though, we also pay attention to the rising number of people in Western society who have a lively interest in spirituality but feel no connection to traditional forms of church and worship. So Marquand is also actively engaged in original, creative, and experimental forms of worship, both for committed Christians and for those exploring the faith.
Attend Marquand five days in a row, and you may encounter an orthodox liturgy of St. John Chrysostom, a Mardi Gras worship party, a service of silent Lenten contemplation, a chapel converted into one of Dante's spheres of heaven, or a worship café. As a student at Yale Divinity School, you may well have taken part in designing one of these services.
From traditional worship to brave experiment, from ancient liturgy to post-modern praise, from the heart of America to global worship, Marquand's mission is to be worshipful, educational, and ecumenical, and we look forward to welcoming you here.
Services take place in Marquand every weekday classes are in session. All services are open to the community.
For more information, contact marquand@yale.edu.

name: Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project
mission: The Marshall-Brennan Constitutional Literacy Project is a national civics education program that sends law students into public high schools to teach courses in constitutional law and oral advocacy. These courses focus primarily on educating high schoolers about their constitutional rights.

name: Math Help Desk
mission: Volunteers at MHD will assist with any math question, no matter how big or small. Our services range from tutoring entry-level courses, to try to help understand mathematics-related research papers.

name: Medical Swahili
mission: To encourage the learning and practice of medical Kiswahili, both for the language's intrinsic value and for the insight it can provide into the nuances of the clinician-patient interaction in Kiswahili-speaking countries

name: School of Management Program on Entrepreneurship
School of Nursing - Medical Spanish Club
MATHCOUNTS Outreach; a Yale Undergraduate Organization
mission:
(1) Build a lasting interest in mathematics and problem solving among middle school students in the New Haven area through weekly tutoring sessions.
(2) Support middle school students in their mathematical educations through review and enrichment of material.
(3) Create a platform for students to apply their skills through annual competitions and events.
(4) Serve the New Haven community by improving the general quality of mathematics education.

name: Matriculate Chapter at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Matriculate's mission is to empower high-achieving, low-moderate income high school students to make the leap to colleges and universities of best fit with support and advising from undergraduates at Yale.

name: MB&B's Committee of Climate and Diversity
mission: Our mission is to promote diversity, equity and inclusion in the department of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry. We are dedicated to creating an inclusive environment where all members, regardless of their background, feel valued, respected, and empowered to contribute their best. We want to strengthen the sense of community, mutual understanding and belonging through shared activities and social events dedicated to DEI topics.

name: McDougal Center
mission:
The McDougal Center staff and fellows organize many fun programs and events to help you connect with other GSAS students, explore New Haven, and build a strong sense of community. Please feel free to reach out to us if we can help you!

To learn more about our events:
- check your email for our weekly emails, which are sent to all GSAS students each week - also in your "My Inbox" in Yale Connect under "More" or on Group Page as "Newsletters" or in Yale Connect App as a Push notification
- view McDougal Center events on Yale Connect App & Web

name: MDiv Cohort Group
mission: Space for MDiv current students. Receive news and updates from your year group reps, schedule events together as a program community and connect with other MDiv'ers!

name: Mecha de Yale -- a Yale Student Organization
category: Advocacy/Policy, Cultural, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: MEChA de Yale is an organization of students in pursuit of social justice, community empowerment and cultural awareness.

name: Med Out the Vote
mission: Med Out the Vote (MOtV) is a voter registration/mobilization campaign initiative by AMSA. We are a non-partisan campaign that is dedicated to increasing the civic engagement of healthcare professionals.

name: Medical Mandarin Interest Group
mission: The Medical Mandarin Interest Group (MMIG) is dedicated to helping students develop their Mandarin skills in an effort to provide the best possible care to an increasingly diverse patient population.

name: Medical Student For Compassion and Choices
Medical Students for a Sustainable Future at Yale
mission: The PSR Yale School of Medicine Student Chapter aims to promote human health in Connecticut and the New Haven community by addressing pollution and climate change through education, service and advocacy.

name: Medical Students with Disabilities and Chronic Illnesses at Yale School of Medicine
mission:
MSDCI at Yale School of Medicine is an official chapter of Medical Students with Disabilities and Chronic Illnesses National (MSDCI National). This organization shall advocate for a medical field that is inclusive to care providers with disabilities and chronic illnesses and empower people with disabilities and chronic illnesses to pursue careers in the field of medicine. The group aims to:
- Educate future healthcare workers on the experiences of people living with disabilities and chronic illnesses, with an aim to promote the dignity, agency and individuality of each person's lived experience.
- Promote the dissemination of information relative to disability issues in the field of medical education;
- Explore and possibly resolve the unique challenges, obstacles, and responsibilities specific to medical students and physicians with disabilities and/or chronic illness;
- Provide opportunities for disabled and chronically ill medical students to learn about and give back to local communities through service.
- Represent people with disabilities and chronic illnesses within the health care community at Yale School of Medicine.
- Be a resource for information on matters related to disability and chronic illness.
- Provide a forum for discussion of issues concerning the health and rights of people with disabilities and chronic illnesses.
- Provide a link between students and faculty with disabilities and chronic illnesses.
- Support intersectional advocacy efforts at Yale School of Medicine.
- Create a community for Yale School of Medicine students living with disabilities & chronic illness.
- Advocate for increased representation of and education about disability and chronic illness in the Yale School of Medicine curriculum and clinical training opportunities.

name: Medieval Literature Exploration Club
mission: MLEC strives to provide an opportunity for Yale students passionate about medieval cultures to explore Yale's vast medieval studies and cultural resources. Too often, medieval studies focus on Medieval Europe, and we hope to actively engage with other cultures and learn about their practices. Engagement includes group discussions, visits to archives and museums, and occasional medieval-themed events to introduce more Yalie's to the field.

name: Meditation and Mindfulness at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: We aim to facilitate regular meditation and mindfulness practice among Yalies. This is done by organising weekly group sits and helping to ensure there are facilities available for come and go private sessions. We also strengthen each other's practices through regular discussions of relevant literature. We are open to people from all meditative backgrounds.

name: MedSci
mission: MedSci is an education-focused organization and strives to strengthen Yale students' relationship with the local community and benefit all involved with its programs. Through its education outreach program, elementary school students will be encouraged to explore higher-level science concepts and older mentors will have the opportunity to build their leadership and public speaking skills.

name: Mental Health Advocacy, Resource, and Care Helpers
Methodist Studies
mission: This is a space for YDS students, alumni, and colleagues who share in the Methodist tradition in its many diverse manifestations such as AME, Korean Methodists, and United Methodists. We welcome all who identify with the Wesleyan heritage as well as new seekers searching for a circle of friends in faith. We provide a forum for mutual upbuilding, spiritual formation, doctrinal and polity concerns, and contact with local Methodist clergy. We meet for fellowship, worship, guest speakers, community service, and other activities.

name: Middle Eastern and North African Law Students' Association
Migration Alliance at Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: MAY is a coalition of undergraduate students passionately devoted to aiding refugees, immigrants, and all other migrants in Greater New Haven – through advocacy and direct service.

name: Military History Society
mission: To promote the discussion and study of military history and military strategy among members of Yale College and the wider Yale community by hosting events including wargames, strategy games, and presentations.

name: Mixed Company
mission: Mixed Company is an undergraduate organization formed primarily to promote public appreciation of group harmony singing and to educate students at Yale and other educational institutions and the general public about such music.

name: MonstRAASity
category: Cultural, Performance: Dance, AACC Affiliate Org
mission: The goals of MonstRAASity are: To provide an opportunity for students to learn and observe the Gujarati folkdance Raas; to perform at cultural events and other venues across the University; to contribute to the cultural diversity of the University community by means of sharing Gujarati culture.

name: Mormon Studies Society
mission: To facilitate discussions about a dynamic, growing academic field studying Mormon theology, history, and culture!

name: Morris Tyler Moot Court of Appeals
Nepali Students Society at Yale
category: Cultural, Food/Culinary, Social, AACC Affiliate Org, International
mission: NSS is an organization for Yale students of Nepali descent, and students that aim to educate and promote Nepal and Nepali culture. This organization provides a forum on campus for political, social, and cultural conversations. Through numerous events and strong community communication, we hope to create positive connections between students of Nepali origin and the local communities around and at Yale.

name: MusicConnect at Yale: An Undergraduate Outreach Initiative
mission: Our mission statement is to bring together musicians from Yale with the local New Haven community. Yale instrumentalists and vocalists of all levels who are driven by their passion for music and willingness to bring music to people who need it most are welcome to join. A major tenet of our organization is providing live outreach music performances for the New Haven community at day-care centers, senior living facilities, hospices, etc. We hope to soothe and entertain those who would not otherwise have many opportunities to engage with live music and strive to make a difference in their day.  In addition to outreach performances, we seek to provide informal music classes (covering instrumental/vocal instruction as well as general music theory classes) to children in the New Haven community. Members will design a music curriculum, which will be implemented at after-school workshops at elementary schools and social enrichment programs such as L.E.A.P. We hope to engage younger children through music,  helping them become exposed to different styles and ultimately explore their passion for music.

name: Muslim Law Students' Association
mission: The Muslim Law Students' Association serves as a vehicle for gathering Muslims and others interested in learning about Islamic legal issues and issues of concern to Muslims and other minorities.

name: National Center for Law and Economic Justice
National Lawyers Guild
mission: The National Lawyers Guild (NLG) is dedicated to the need for basic change in the structure of our political and economic system.

name: National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBCChE)-Yale
mission: The mission of NOBCChE includes building an eminent community of scientists and engineers by increasing the number of underrepresented minorities in the fields of chemistry, chemical engineering, and related disciplines. NOBCChE-Yale and its partners will use a combination of in-person and virtual meetings, workshops, demonstrations, awards, and other events to deliver programming that advances the shared objectives of NOBCChE-Yale and the national organization.

name: National Society of Black Engineers
mission: The National Society of Black Engineers, as a national student and professional based organization, does hereby dedicate itself to the development of intensive programs for increasing African-American and other ethnic minority participation in the field of engineering and engineering technology.  These programs will be initiated both within and outside the campus community and will serve to strengthen relations between professional industry and the African-American community.  Members of the organization are encouraged to join and participate in their individual professional societies.  This organization will endeavor to provide general counseling to all members.  The Yale University Chapter of the National Society of Black Engineers declares its intention to fulfill the mission of the national organization on Yale's campus and in the New Haven community.

name: Native American Cultural Center
mission: The NACC strives to maintain a permanent and prominent Indigenous presence at Yale that incorporates and supports the success of future Native leaders through recruitment, encouragement, mentoring, service, and the fostering of a community that makes Yale the most sought after Ivy Institution for Indigenous achievement, research and solidarity.

name: Native American Law Students' Association
mission: The mission of the Yale Native American Law Students Association (NALSA) is twofold. First, we are dedicated to providing personal, professional, and cultural support to Yale's Native American law students and fostering a community among all law students who are interested in Indian legal issues. Second, we are committed to educating Yale's student body about Indian law, tribal sovereignty, and indigenous rights. NALSA is inclusive and welcomes all members of the YLS community.

name: Native and Indigenous Student Association at Yale — a Student Organization
mission:
The Native and Indigenous Student Association at Yale (NISAY) [formerly known as ANAAY until 2021] is a student-run political and cultural organization that empowers Indigenous students and advocates for causes throughout Indigenous communities in the global context.
NISAY is devoted to the establishment of a Native presence on Campus. The group works towards Indigenous cultural awareness of the Yale Community with a Native perspective through panels, speaker programs, and other events throughout the year.

name: Native Crossroads
mission: Native Crossroads celebrates and elevates Native presence, scholarship, and lifeways at Yale Divinity School. As relatives from many tribes and nations, we come together to affirm and encourage each other as we undertake diverse programs of theological and religious study. As scholars and community leaders, we open up conversations that explore the complex relationship between Native traditions and Christian faith. As teachers, healers, and advocates, we seek to bring the power of Native voices into the institutional and ceremonial life of the YDS community. Overall, we seek to weave the vibrant patterns of Indigenous knowledge-sharing, feasting, and storytelling into the academic, liturgical, and social fabric of the divinity school and the university.

name: New Haven Resource for Essay and Application College Help
mission: New Haven REACH is a student-run organization that seeks to provide the information and support necessary for New Haven youth to access the higher education best suited to their dreams, potential, and ambitions. REACH was founded by graduates of the Wilbur Cross Class of 2011, and we now have Yale student volunteers who hail from all over America and all over the world. We all share the core belief that no one should be shut out from attending college just because they don't have the information and support they need to apply.

name: New Haven Urban Debate League
mission: Our mission is to empower New Haven's students with the public speaking and critical thinking skills necessary to lead the future.

name: New York City Law Department - Appeals Division
New York Civil Liberties Union New York
Nondenominational Prayer Group
mission: Nondenominational Student Group is for students looking for community, spiritual growth, and a space to engage in prayer and other Christian spiritual activities. We provide a supportive environment where students with different backgrounds can come together, fostering personal and communal growth. Through our gatherings and events, we aim to create opportunities for students to deepen their relationship with Christ, build meaningful relationships, and find support on their spiritual journeys.

name: Office for Graduate Student Development and Diversity (OGSDD), GSAS
mission: The Office for Graduate Student Development and Diversity (OGSDD) is committed to building and maintaining a nurturing and caring community of scholars where students from diverse backgrounds and experiences are supported in their professional and intellectual goals and pursuits.

name: Office of Gender and Campus Culture
mission: Preventing, recognizing, and responding to sexual misconduct is a community-wide project: every one of us has a part to play in making our campus culture as safe, respectful, and supportive as it can be. To build our individual and collective skills, all members of the Yale community have an annual sexual misconduct training requirement.

name: Office of Global Affairs and Planetary Health
Office of International Students & Scholars
mission: Over 6000 international students and scholars from more than 120 countries call Yale University their home away from home. You come from Albania and Zimbabwe and many places in between and you are making untold contributions to this university. The OISS is here to help and support you throughout your Yale experience and beyond, be it a question about your immigration status or your transition to this new culture and community. We look forward to getting to know you!

name: Office of LGBTQ Resources at Yale University
mission: The Office of LGBTQ Resources supports and empowers students, faculty, staff, scholars, and alumni of all sexual orientations, gender identities, and expressions to strengthen and unite our Yale University community.

name: Office of Senator Richard Blumenthal, Judiciary Committee
Sunday Sports Club
mission:
Sunday Sports Club is a student group at the Yale School of Music that provides opportunities for YSM'ers to play a variety of outdoor sports together. The group's mission is to foster community and promote student wellness.
---
Sunday Sports Club is committed to ensuring accessibility for people with disabilities. We will do whatever is needed to ensure that everyone is able to take part in SSC activities.

name: QuestBridge- a student organization
mission: The Quest Scholars Network is a network of QuestBridge Scholars attending partner schools. The purpose of this network is to provide community and a support network for the Scholars. We work to provide a welcoming, supportive community for the Scholars on campus, as well as any other Yale students who identify as Low-income or First-generation.

name: versicolor
mission: Our mission is to study, rehearse, and perform contemporary music, as well as music of the last hundred years, written by composers of diverse backgrounds and identities.

name: Office of the Attorney General - Illinois
Office of the Attorney General of New Jersey
Office of the Los Angeles City Attorney
Office of the Secretary and Vice President for University Life
Office of the Secretary and Vice President for University Life
Opera Theatre of Yale College
category: Performance: Instruments, Performance: Singing, Performance: Theater
mission: The Opera Theatre of Yale College (OTYC) is the undergraduate opera company at Yale University. Our organization is entirely student-run; every show offers our members the opportunity to learn firsthand the mechanics of performing and producing an opera. Our members are singers, instrumentalists, conductors, theatre technicians, costume and set designers, choreographers, and dancers. OTYC is an immersive extracurricular experience that prepares young artists and administrators for professional life after Yale. We are committed to bringing creative, thoughtful, and innovative opera productions to the Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Orthodox Christian Fellowship of Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: By creating a branch of the Orthodox Christian Fellowship at Yale we hope to connect Orthodox college students and those interested in the Orthodox faith together by providing information, talks, and activities to strengthen the Orthodox community at Yale.

name: Orville H. Schell, Jr. Center for International Human Rights
oSTEM (Out in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) Graduate Chapter at Yale University
mission:
oSTEM empowers LGBTQ+ people in STEM to succeed personally,
academically, and professionally by cultivating environments and
communities that nurture innovation, leadership, and advocacy.

name: Out in Public
mission: Out in Public seeks to promote diversity and awareness at Yale School of Public Health by providing a platform for students to advocate for the needs and concerns of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) community at YSPH and beyond, by creating a personal and professional network for the LGBTQIA+ community, and by organizing social and academic events aimed at fostering a sense of community at YSPH.

name: Pi Sigma Alpha Beta Rho Political Science Honor Society
mission: Pi Sigma Alpha (PSA) Beta Rho Chapter at Yale is an undergraduate honor society whose purpose is to recognize and promote the highest levels of scholarship and achievement in the field of political science.  Our mission is to stimulate productive scholarship, promote a better understanding of government, promote worthwhile curricular and extracurricular activities related to political science, encourage employment in the government and non-profit sector by providing a forum for graduate school and employment questions, kindle friendships and networking among students and faculty within the department, and serve the community surrounding Yale through public service.

name: Outdoor Climbing at Yale: A Student Organization
mission: The goal of OCAY is to foster a climbing-focused outdoor culture and community. In order to do this, OCAY aims to create a community of Yale students, faculty and staff who are already outdoor climbers, mountaineers or alpinists, and to provide safety workshops and other training opportunities for new and experienced climbers alike in a safe and controlled environment. In addition to on-campus events including workshops and social events, OCAY's ultimate goal is to lead outdoor climbing trips where members can learn from each other. As OCAY is expressly focused on outdoor climbing, we can focus our resources on providing the highest-quality climbing workshops, events, and outdoor trips.

name: Outdoor Recreation Industry SIG
mission:
The Outdoor Rec Industry SIG (ORec SIG) aims to provide a space for YSE students to discuss the future of the outdoor industry, diving into its impacts and opportunities for environmental, economic and social benefit. This may include historic narratives on who recreates outside and why, the role of private companies (Patagonia, REI, The North Face, etc.), public land management policy (National Park Service, U.S. Forest Service, Bureau of Land Management, etc.) as well as nonprofits that connect communities of all types to the outdoors. Topics for the SIG will cover sustainability in supply chains, innovations in materials, opportunities for justice, equity, diversity and inclusion in outdoor spaces, economic development in the rural United States, and others. Additionally, confronting racism both within Yale and in the outdoor recreation industry at large is central to the mission of ORec SIG. Additionally, ORec SIG notes that the ability of people across the country to enjoy time outside is enabled by land that was stolen from Indigenous peoples.
ORec SIG seeks student contributors to the "New Directions in Outdoor Recreation" publication, which showcases student writing on various aspects of the Outdoor Recreation Industry. https://medium.com/new-directions-in-outdoor-recreation-at-yale-fes

name: OutLaws
mission: OutLaws is an organization of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) members of the Law School community. Our goals are to provide a community for LGBTQ-identified people within YLS, to provide opportunities and connections for members of the YLS community who are interested in LGBTQ rights, and to advocate for legal issues of interest to the LGBTQ community.

name: OutPatient
mission: As YSM's LGBTQIA+ student group, OutPatient aims to build a community for the LGBTQIA+ identifying individuals and allies among medical students, and to spark conversation about health care issues facing the LGBTQIA+ patient populations. We aim to increase awareness, visibility, and education focusing on LGBTQIA+ populations, related resources for the New Haven communities, and other associated concerns.

name: Pacific Islander Student Association at Yale
mission: The Indigenous Peoples of Oceania at Yale (IPO) is dedicated to providing Oceanic students with the opportunity to build community, advocate for, and celebrate the identities, traditions, and diverse experiences of those Indigenous to Pasifika. IPO strives to uplift Oceanic student voices within the broader Yale community and serve as a platform for Oceanic-centered social events, educational opportunities, and student activism.

name: PALS: Tutoring and Mentoring Group
mission: PALS' mission is to reach as many students from first to sixth grade as possible with quality weekly tutoring. We focus on core academic skills and building individual relationships with our students. We particularly seek students that lack the opportunity to receive tutoring elsewhere.

name: Party of the Left
mission: We, the Party of the Left, are a community devoted to political discourse. As such, we seek both to develop our Members as people and leaders, and to develop a new vision of the American Left. Our means are spirited discussion and formal debate of the politics, policies, and philosophies that divide our community. We value intellectual integrity: the willingness to examine one's innermost beliefs in a manner that is both honest and rigorous. Internally, we compete to present compelling visions of the Left. Externally, we test our ideas and abilities against our ideological opponents. We seek to bring discourse to the outside world, and the outside world to discourse. Together, we strive to advance the Party, the Yale Political Union, and the Left.

name: Pastry Arts at Yale – an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Pastry Arts at Yale is an undergraduate organization that will foster camaraderie and fellowship among those with a shared love for pastry arts. It seeks to build a collaborative community for developing advanced pastry skills and professional techniques, while also holding bake sales to donate proceeds to charitable causes.

name: Qui Transtulit Sustinet
mission:
QTS is a student organization that seeks to foster a safe space and
to create a sense of community for transfer students at YLS. QTS
leadership will gather the institutional knowledge that current
transfer students possess to facilitate the adaptation process of
future transfers. It will also make demands to the administration
and other student-run organizations regarding the needs of transfer
students.

name: Pathways to Science - for Graduate & Professional Student Volunteers
mission: Pathways to Science is Yale's coordinated STEM outreach infrastructure that provides an overarching infrastructure for the many and varied STEM programs and events for local pre-college students at Yale. Guided by a steering committee of Yale senior scientists and administrators, the Office of New Haven Affairs serves as a central hub for this initiative, both assisting Yale faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates in designing and implementing STEM programming as well as managing contacts and relationships with participating school districts, teachers, parents, and pre-college students. The more than 1,800 Pathways to Science Scholars are considered the youngest members of Yale's scientific community and are invited throughout the year to special events, academic lectures, demonstrations, hands-on activities, summer programs, and research opportunities.

name: Paul Tsai China Center
mission:
Founded by Professor Paul Gewirtz in 1999 as the China Law Center, the Paul Tsai China Center is the primary home for activities related to China at Yale Law School. The Center is a unique institution dedicated to helping advance China's legal reforms, improving U.S.–China relations, and increasing understanding of China in the United States.
In interaction with research and teaching at Yale, the Paul Tsai China Center works collaboratively with a broad range of top experts in the Chinese government, universities, and civil society on concrete projects designed to have a positive practical impact. Our Center has an established track record in helping to further a broad range of legal reforms in China. Cooperative projects have focused particularly on issues of judicial reform, criminal justice reform, administrative and regulatory reform, and public interest law. Projects involve a range of activities, including workshops and seminars in the United States and China, research visits to Yale and to China, and books or articles by Chinese or U.S. scholars.
The Paul Tsai China Center also conducts research and convenes high-level Track II and Track 1.5 meetings on a broad range of U.S.–China foreign policy issues. The centerpiece of this work is the Dialogue on U.S.–China Relations, a thriving channel since 2012 for top U.S. and Chinese figures to develop and provide timely policy recommendations for both governments. The dialogue convenes carefully selected former officials and practitioners to work toward strategic and diplomatic innovation over the full range of issues in the U.S.–China relationship, with dual emphases on security and economic issues. The Center also hosts top Chinese and U.S. scholars and policy practitioners at Yale as guests and visiting scholars who produce original research and interact with the broader Yale community.
In 2016, Yale Law School received an extraordinary gift of $30 million in honor of its distinguished alumnus, the late Dr. Paul C. Tsai, '54 LL.M , '57 J.S.D., to support the continuing work of the China Center. This generous gift was given by Paul Tsai's son, Joseph C. Tsai, Yale College, B.A. '86; Yale Law School, J.D. '90. In recognition of this gift, the Center was renamed the Paul Tsai China Center.
The Director of the Paul Tsai China Center is Professor Paul Gewirtz. Prior to establishing the Center in 1999, Professor Gewirtz was on leave from Yale University from 1997–1998 and was a part of President Bill Clinton's administration, where he served as Special Representative for the Presidential Rule of Law Initiative at the U.S. Department of State. In that post, he developed and led the U.S.–China initiative to cooperate in the legal field that President Clinton and China's President Jiang Zemin launched at their October 1997 Summit.

name: Peace and Dialogue Leadership Initiative
mission:
1. To convey a nuanced understanding of the Israeli-­Palestinian Conflict and the region as a whole by connecting high-level strategic dialogue with realities on the ground,
2. To provide students with the tools necessary to think about the United States' proper role in the U.S.-Israel relationship, its role in the Israeli-Palestinian relationship, and, more broadly, its role in the region,
3.T o foster civil­/military understanding and dialogue,
4. To provide an incisive look into Israeli society, culture, and politics, while simultaneously grappling with the unique security challenges facing both the U.S. and her allies in the region,
5. To actively foster a community on college campuses interested in engaging with and discussing these issues.

name: People, Equity, and the Environment Learning Community
mission: This LC helps students develop the skills they need to thoughtfully critique and improve the relationship between people and the planet, with a focus on deep-seated, systemic challenges. Emphasis is placed on the interplay among the environment, systemic social issues, and the emerging environmental justice movement.

name: Peristalsis Dance Group
mission: Peristalsis serves to bring light movement and dance classes to patients at the Yale-New Haven Hospital pediatric psychiatric unit.

name: Persian Graduate Students and Scholars Association at Yale
mission: Persian Students and Scholars Association at Yale organizes cultural/traditional events such as Nowrooz (Persian New Year), Yalda. Such events are celebrated worldwide by various ethno-linguistic groups. This organization also helps its members to connect with other students and scholar and make a community.

name: Persian Students Association at Yale
mission: To create a space on campus which allows students to engage and appreciate Persian culture through social events and learning opportunities, in addition to connecting with fellow Persians.

name: Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine: An Undergraduate Publication is an initiative intended to create an inclusive, positive space for engagement with issues pertaining to Israel, Palestine and the region. By welcoming a diverse group of individuals and perspectives into this literary forum, we aim to cultivate and expand healthy and open dialogue on these issues on campus and in the Yale community. Submissions to the Perspectives: The Yale Journal on Israel and Palestine may be academic papers, personal essays, perspective pieces, or artistic contributions. All contributions are required to be respectful in their treatment of other students, perspectives, and demographic groups. Submissions will be evaluated by the Editorial Board and reviewed for publication.

name: Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Interest Group
Physicians for Human Rights
mission: The YSM chapter of PHR seeks to promote the role of medical students as advocates for health and human rights locally, nationally and globally. Our chapter supports initiatives such as the Refugee Health Literacy Program, Adult Refugee Clinic shadowing, and the Free Aleppo University (FAU) Medical School Partnership.

name: Pitches and Tones A Cappella
mission: Pitches & Tones was founded in 2011 as an a cappella group independent of all other singing groups and councils. We perform a variety of member-arranged songs covering a broad spectrum of genres, often coupled with innovative choreography. Our objective is to find creative, entertaining, and enriching ways to share our passion for music with audiences both at Yale and beyond. Giving back is also central to our members, and we often perform at several informal charity events each year.

name: Plant-Based for Public Health
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, Food/Culinary, Health/Wellness, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Social, Special Interest
mission: Plant-Based for Public Health (PB4PH) at YSPH is dedicated to recognizing, amplifying, and celebrating the connection between nutrition, individual wellbeing, population health, animal welfare, and environmental health. PB4PH embraces the One Health perspective. We exist to empower individuals through education, community advocacy, and wholehearted inclusion to wield the power of accessible dietary and lifestyle choices for the promotion and progression of public health. We advocate for a healthier, more equitable, sustainable, and compassionate food system, and recognize that public health depends on the wellbeing of humans, animals, and the planet.

name: Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Interest Group
mission: To generate and support student interest in PRS

name: Point of Care Ultrasound Interest Group
Polish Society at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Our group provides a place for Polish students to meet and practice cultural traditions. We encourage language practice as well and a space to talk with Polish language faculty.

name: Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning
mission: The Yale Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning promotes equitable and engaged teaching throughout the University, and supports students across the curriculum as they take ownership of their learning. As part of a world-class research institution, we provide training, consultations, and resources designed to make teaching and learning more public and collaborative, so that every Yale instructor experiences the satisfaction that results from teaching well, and every student develops the critical reflection that marks deep and independent learning.

name: Poorvu Center: Academic Strategies Program
mission: Our mission is to help all Yale undergraduates become active, empowered learners in their academic lives at Yale. Through peer academic mentoring and interactive workshops, we hope to provide you with the tools to help propel you towards your goals.

name: Poorvu Center: Faculty Programs and Initiatives
mission: The Yale Poorvu Center for Teaching and Learning promotes equitable and engaged teaching throughout the University. As part of a world-class research institution, we provide training, consultations, and resources designed to make teaching and learning more public and collaborative. We hope every Yale instructor experiences the satisfaction that results from teaching well.

name: Public Health First-Generation & Low-Income Students
mission: To create a strong community consisting of First-Generation & Low-Income Students at Yale School of Public Health.

name: Public Health Innovation Exchange (PHIX)
mission: Connect YSPH students into the greater Yale entrepreneurial community and create a supportive student working group to achieve entrepreneurial success.

name: Public Health Teaching Fellow Training
mission: To help YSPH teaching fellows to complete all of the required training in order to be effective teaching fellows.

name: Poorvu Center: Graduate and Postdoctoral Teaching Development
mission: Graduate and Postdoc Teaching Development initiatives serve many populations -- graduate students, professional school students, and postdoctoral fellows.  We offer an extensive set of workshops for new teachers that encourage creativity and promote good teaching practices.  These workshops include the Fundamentals of Teaching (tailored to particular disciplines) and Advanced Teaching Workshops, on themes ranging from active learning to universal design, to inclusive assessment. We also offer support for graduate and postdoc teaching through classroom observations and one-on-one consultations, which allow new teachers to share challenges in a neutral space.  Graduate students and postdocs who want to do more intensive teaching development can pursue the Certificate in College Teaching Preparation (CCTP), the requirements for which include teaching, participating in workshops, observing others' teaching, and preparing a capstone teaching portfolio.  At the heart of our program is a group of 22 McDougal Teaching Fellows who run many of our workshops and manager classroom observations.  Other opportunities for graduate student development include the Associates in Teaching program, which allows a graduate student to teach as instructor of record in partnership with a faculty member, and the Teaching Innovation Projects grant, which invites fresh ideas for using digital tools in the classroom.  The Graduate Teaching Program also serves the teaching needs of individual departments, promotes faculty-student mentoring, and responds to emerging developments in research about teaching.

name: Poorvu Center: Graduate Writing Lab
mission: The Graduate Writing Lab creates and administers programs to help graduate and professional students become confident and proficient academic writers and presenters of their research. Through individual and classroom programming, we promote best practices in developing written and oral communication skills.

name: Poorvu Center: Yale College Writing Center
Precision Medicine Interest Group
mission: PMIG is a student-led organization dedicated to promoting student education and interests in precision medicine – a rapidly evolving, multidisciplinary field that seeks to tailor therapeutic and preventative care. Throughout the academic year, we will organize talks and panels from leaders in the field to help students to explore clinical, research, and career opportunities in precision medicine.

name: Preventative and Accessible Traditional Healing
mission:
Our mission is to form a space that serves as a community for people interested in engaging with eastern medicine principles (Ayurveda, Traditional Chinese Medicine) as a way to empower themselves through knowledge of preventive medicine, balance, and connection to the natural world. We believe that people should not have to purchase their health. Access to the medicinal qualities of the natural world should be a right available to everyone. Through deconstructing the prevalent neo-colonial understanding of healthcare and the human relationship with the environment, health becomes fundamental for all living beings.
We aim to dispel stigmas surrounding eastern medicine and emphasize the power of symbiosis between eastern and conventional medical practices. Changing the context of healthcare involves:
- Coexistence with western medicine
- Decolonize understanding of health
- Understand eastern medicine principles in the context of community and the ways in which it transcends healthcare
- Acknowledge the body has various dimensions of well-being
- Encourage mindfulness to enhance the relationship between spirit and body

name: Preventative Medicine Interest Group
mission: The goal of the Preventative Medicine Interest Group is to make members more . familiar with foundational aspects of exercise physiology, biopsychosocial aspects of exercise in communities, and the implementation of exercise as a treatment in medical care. Through lectures and workshops, we hope to explore when, how, and why to recommend and help people begin and maintain lifestyle changes related to physical activity. So when someone comes to you wanting to reduce their blood pressure or improve their insulin sensitivity--and they want to do more than just take medications--you can confidently help them explore a variety of evidence-based options. We plan to discuss research on physical activity, aerobic exercise, and anaerobic exercise and how they affect many of the most common health maladies we're likely to encounter as healthcare providers. We also plan to lead hands-on workshops in the Harkness gym so that you can learn how to implement the research. We don't intend to train you to become personal trainers--doing so is beyond the purview of this endeavor--though we hope you'll be familiar enough with these ideas and methods so that you can make confident suggestions to patients. Of course, we also value your feedback, so if there's anything you'd like us to address, then please let us know and we can try to do so.

name: Program on Refugees, Forced Displacement, and Humanitarian Responses
Proof of the Pudding
mission: Proof of the Pudding was founded to extend the male-dominated tradition of a cappella at Yale to women and continues today for that same goal. Proof strives to make music at the highest level and provide group members with the opportunity to perform for audiences on campus and around the world. Above all, Proof aims to fulfill our mission of cultivating sisterhood and song that lives on for future generations.

name: Public Defender Service for the District of Columbia
Redhot & Blue
mission: Through the dedication of our members, past and present, we've come together to chase the bounds of musical possibility, while always looking back to the greats who inspired the conception of Redhot & Blue. We are dedicated to maintaining our history of strong musicality, both vocally and with our arrangements, all of which are created by current or former members, as well as sharing that musicality with audiences of all ages and backgrounds.

name: ReDirected Studies
mission: Yale ReDirected Studies commits itself to reflecting on the limitations of the 'Western' intellectual tradition and articulating alternatives to said tradition. With this in consideration, we strive to focus on 'non-Western' intellectual and cultural works typically excluded from these 'canons,' while consistently re-evaluating how framing as such edifies concepts like the 'West.' ReDirected hopes to accomplish our goals by inviting Yale's wider community to explore traditions that developed independently from the stereotypical 'West,' whether wholly or in part.

name: Reformed Students Group
mission: The Reformed Student Group hosts weekly student-led worship services intended to make room for non-academic spiritual reflection and building meaningful community. Created by students in the Reformed Studies Program, the services are often led by students belonging to Reformed and Reformed-adjacent traditions and borrow from Presbyterian (PCUSA) liturgies. However, the services are broadly ecumenical and open to all. The Reformed Student Group provides a space to explore what it means to be Reformed in the 21st century. In addition to our weekly worship, the group meets for more traditional PCUSA communion services on the first Sunday evening of each month. These services include a student-led homily and are presided over by an ordained minister in the Reformed tradition.

name: Refugee and Immigrant Student Education
mission: RISE is a tutoring and mentoring organization that works with immigrants and refugees in New Haven to overcome language and cultural barriers they may face. Our team of tutors works through weekly in-school and in-home sessions in a variety of public schools and family homes. Our tutors work with a curriculum designed by our team, and we provide resources necessary for our ESL based programming. In addition to these weekly sessions, we organize monthly community events to allow for cultural exchanges to benefit the greater New Haven community, the immigrant and refugee populations, and the Yale community.

name: Reproductive Health Equity Now
mission:
Reproductive Health Equity Now (RHEN) at the Yale School of Public Health is a student-led group dedicated to advocating, mobilizing, and organizing around total reproductive healthcare equity on-campus, in the US, and globally. We recognize that as future public health professionals, we play a critical role in ensuring reproductive rights, access, and justice for all. Through peer-to-peer education, engagement, and action, collaboration with academic and community partners, and learning from the women and femmes of color at the forefront of this movement, we work to progress access to all reproductive healthcare—birth control, abortion, and gender-affirming care included.
We recognize the intersectionality of this work and strive to also utilize a reproductive justice framework. Reproductive justice was developed in 1994 by the group "Women of African Descent for Reproductive Justice," and is defined as "the human right to maintain personal bodily autonomy, have children, not have children, and parent the children we have in safe and sustainable communities" (SisterSong Women of Color Reproductive Justice Collective). Reproductive healthcare equity is a part of reproductive justice and focuses on creating a more equitable healthcare system for those who have been marginalized. In working towards this goal, we hope to add to this larger movement for mutual and collective justice.

name: Roman Catholic Fellowship at Yale Divinity School
mission: RCF exists to bring the Catholic students, faculty, and staff of YDS together as a community to learn together, grow in our Catholic faith, and get involved in local community events and service opportunities.

name: Rural Students Alliance at Yale
mission: Recognizing that students from small towns and rural communities have particular experiences that are unique from their urban peers and impact the way they experience Yale, the Rural Students Alliance of Yale is a group for rural students at Yale to get to know and support one another with the goal of improving the experience of rural students at Yale. We also aim to increase the visibility of rurality on Yale's campus, not only highlighting rural members of its student body but also increasing the presence of rurality in academic inquiry through guest speakers, panels, film screenings, and more.

name: Sabrosura: Yale's Undergraduate Premier Latin Dance Team
category: Cultural, Performance: Dance, Social, AfAm Affiliate Org, La Casa  Affiliate Org, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: Sabrosura's mission is to promote and practice cultural expression and celebration through the medium of Latin dance. We hope to provide a space for students interested in Latin Dance, regardless of their cultural backgrounds, to teach and share their love of Latin Dance with Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council
mission: The mission of the Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council is to represent the undergraduates at Saint Thomas More Catholic Chapel & Center at Yale. The Saint Thomas More Undergraduate Council collaborates with the Assistant Chaplains to plan social events and programming for specifically for undergraduates throughout the academic year. Programming includes study breaks, social justice opportunities, intellectual and spiritual development.

name: Salus Populi Foundation at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Salus Populi Foundation at Yale's mission is to offer undergraduates an avenue to engage with Yale's world-class development-economics faculty, research programs, and the Yale Economic Growth Center to prepare students to be at the vanguard of welfare-maximizing policy-formation. By bringing together undergraduates, faculty, and policy practitioners under a collaborative, multidisciplinary framework, SPF hopes to research, debate, and devise innovative solutions to pressing problems in international economic, social, and political development. We aim to foster an intellectual community on campus who are passionate about efforts to enhance socio-economic welfare within developing countries. Our efforts are deeply motivated by Cicero's maxim, salus populi suprema lex esto ('the welfare of the people should be the supreme law'.)

name: SAYPH Advanced Professional MPH Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Advanced Professional MPH Students

name: SAYPH BA-BS/MPH Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the BA-BS/MPH Students

name: SAYPH Biostatistics and HI Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Biostatistics Department

name: SAYPH CDE Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for CDE Students

name: SAYPH EHS Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for Environmental Health Sciences Students

name: SAYPH EMD and EID Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for EMD Students

name: SAYPH Executive Online MPH Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for the Executive MPH Program

name: SAYPH HCM Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for HCM Students

name: SAYPH HP Group
mission: SAYPH Subgroup for HP Students

name: Student Association of Yale School of Public Health
mission:
SAYPH is organized by YSPH students for YSPH students. SAYPH works to enhance the experience of each student at YSPH by sponsoring educational and social activities, providing a forum for students' ideas and concerns, and acting as a liaison between students and the administration. Through SAYPH, students get involved in many areas including the following:
Student clubs and organizations
Professional development and alumni relations
Community service and social events at YSPH and in the greater community
Health and wellness promotion
Recruitment of new students to YSPH
New student orientation and commencement activities
SAYPH is led by an Executive Board consisting of a president, professional development chair, treasurer, alumni engagement chair, social chair, community service chair, and communications chair. There are also MPH departmental student representatives, PhD representatives, and MS representatives. Each department elects students to act as a liaison between students, faculty, and administration. All SAYPH positions are filled through a school-wide nomination process that takes place annually.

name: Students for Sustainability and Waste Reduction at YSPH
mission: SWAY works to shift the current consumption practices at YSPH through campaigns such as 1) minimize the use of disposable items at catered events; 2) creating a CSA program for all members of the YSPH community; and 3) support a model for Yale's transition to sustainable consumption and minimalist disposal patterns.

name: The New Haven PAWS Project
mission: Our mission is to emphasize health equity by providing immediate solutions to foot health among those experiencing homelessness in New Haven. The PAWS Project engages the greater Yale community in events centered around foot health including foot washing services and shoe, sock, and hygiene kit giveaways.

name: Womxn of Color for Maternal & Child Health
mission:
Womxn of Color for Maternal & Child Health is a group led by womxn of color passionate about health justice for pregnant people, infants, children, and young people of color. Our mission is to:
- Facilitate interdisciplinary dialogue about health equity from a racial justice perspective,
- Elevate health narratives and health knowledge of people of color,
- Advocate for health policies and solutions alongside communities of color driven by their needs,
- Promote the integration of evidence-informed practices* and holistic healing practices,
- Provide training on combating racism as a root cause of health inequities, and
- Promote equitable engagement between the Yale community, New Haven community and beyond.
*Evidence gathered from both academic and non-academic sources, including peer reviewed articles and laypersons' experiences

name: Yale Biostatistics Student Association
mission: Founded in 2013, Yale Biostatistics Student Association (YBSA) is a student-run nonprofit organization committed to providing biostatistics education and knowledge to Yale communities. YBSA is also the official student chapter of the American Statistical Association at Yale University. YBSA aims to connect everyone who is passionate about biostatistics and help each member further explore their academic and career opportunities in biostatistics.

name: Yale School of Public Health Student Consulting Group
category: Academic, Leadership, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Professional, Service/Volunteering
mission: To provide pro-bono consulting and public health practice to organizations in the Greater New Haven area and beyond, while also creating opportunities for graduate students to advance their education, knowledge, and experience.

name: Schwarzman Center
mission: To leverage dining, conversation, and the arts as part of students' educational experience, convening people across schools, disciplines, and communities for moments of discovery and connection.

name: Scrubs Addressing the Firearm Epidemic
mission: Scrubs Addressing the Firearm Epidemic (SAFE) is a national organization of students, physicians, nurses, and healthcare professionals dedicated to eliminating the American firearm violence epidemic through research, education, and evidence-based policy.

name: Shades A Cappella, Inc.
mission: Shades is an all gender a cappella group founded to celebrate music of the African Diaspora.  It is our objective to offer a unique, musically excellent, and spiritually enriching performance experience to audiences at Yale University and beyond. Drawing from the diverse backgrounds of our members and the oral traditions of Black people across the globe, we strive to portray authentically the complexity of the Black experience.  In addition to mastering the style of our music, we develop an appreciation of its history and roots in order to educate audiences about our music's lineage.

name: SheCode
mission: As our society becomes more and more technologically advanced, computer science becomes increasingly important and relevant.  However, programming is inaccessible to many minority groups, especially women.  We believe that teaching programming skills to girls will inspire and foster an interest in computer science.  Moreover, our classes expose students to a technical field and allow them to create concrete products and instill value of perseverance, creativity, ownership, and achievement.  SheCode wants to lower the initial intimidation barrier of computer science and create a supportive environment where students of all background can learn, collaborate, and create something incredible.

name: Shelby County Public Defender - Memphis Memphis
Sikhs at Yale - a Student Association
mission: Sikhs at Yale (SAY) aims to raise the cultural and spiritual awareness of the Sikh faith among Sikh and non-Sikhs alike on Yale's Campus. In addition, we seek to create and foster a cohesive community through community service and social events as well as to build bridges with other groups.

name: Simplex Sciences
mission: The mission of Simplex Sciences Inc. is to educate students on running and innovating a biotech startup. We focus on areas of research and development, marketing, business operations, finances, sales, customer outreach, etc.

name: Singing Group Council
mission: The Singing Group Council serves as the administrator for the majority of Yale's a cappella community. Our primarily duties are to facilitate the audition process at the start of the year, organize groups' concert dates throughout the second semester, and serve as a liaison between Yale's a cappella community and performance venues in New Haven.

name: The Spizzwinks of Yale University, Inc.
mission:
Founded in 1914, the Spizzwinks(?) of Yale University are America's oldest underclassmen a cappella group.
Taking each 'wink to perform on all six inhabited continents and their hometown, the Spizzwinks are committed to singing, family, service, and music education.

name: Sir Thomas More Lecture Series
mission: The Sir Thomas More Lecture Series is a set of weekly talks delivered over lunch on topics pertaining to politics, philosophy, history, religion, art, the humanities. Guests have ranged from Yale professors to an Austrian Archduke, and attendance is open to any and all Yale students.

name: Smart Woman Securities
mission: Smart Woman Securities (SWS) Yale and aims to empower undergraduate women of all academic backgrounds and all career interests with investment knowledge. Founded in 2010, it is the first finance organization for women at Yale. Through instructive seminars, mentoring initiatives, and meetings with successful investors such as Warren Buffett, SWS provides resources upon which women can build greater knowledge of financial markets. By giving young women direct investment experience while still in college, SWS aims to empower a new generation of women investors for the future.

name: Social Justice and Liberation Reading Group
Socialist Students At Yale
mission:
The Marxists At Yale aim to create a body of students who seek to learn about Marxism and capitalism. Recognizing that Marxism is usually not represented in high schools, we want to balance the political discourse and bring leftist ideology to the students of Yale.
Our goal is to make Marxist theory and ideas more accessible to Yale students, and to showcase the diversity and excellence of some of history's greatest and most fascinating Marxist thinkers.

name: Socially Responsible Surgery
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, Health/Wellness, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Professional, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering
mission:
Recognizing social responsibility as a core value of surgical practice and surgery as an essential component of global health, this committee aims to identify opportunities for leadership, research, and collaboration in the training of globally-minded surgeons committed to surgical equity.
Uniquely poised as a safety-net hospital and academic institution, Boston Medical Center has the opportunity to emerge as a leader in the thought and practice of Socially Responsible Surgery (SRS). We believe in educating and serving our local community as part of the larger global community.

name: Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) - Yale Chapter
mission: SACNAS chapter at Yale will focus on the connection of minority scientists on campus from the undergraduate to faculty level. As a group, we will focus on mentorhsip, science outreach, and resources for scientific development.

name: Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers - SHPE Yale Student Chapter
mission:
The purpose of this student chapter is to:
1) Encourage and promote engineering and related STEM fields to the Hispanic population at Yale University.
2) Increase Hispanic retention in engineering and related STEM fields at Yale University
3) Provide post-graduation advice, resources and opportunities that benefit Hispanic engineering students at Yale University.
4) Create community outreach programs to inspire and encourage children in the New Haven community, especially communities with large Hispanic and minority populations, to pursue careers in engineering and STEM.
5) Provide mentorship and a structured community for Hispanic engineering students at Yale University.

name: Solomon Center for Health Law & Policy
mission:
The Solomon Center for Health Law and Policy at Yale Law School is the first of its kind to focus on the intersection of law and the governance, practice, and business of health care. The Center brings together leading experts and practitioners from the public and private sectors to address cutting-edge questions of health law and policy, and to train the next generation of top health lawyers, industry leaders, policymakers, and academics.
The Center was established to meet a critical need for a new academic and legal-professional discipline that responds to the rapidly evolving environment of health care and its centrality in the nation's economy and government. "Health law" as a field of study in law schools is a relatively new concept; it has yet to be embraced within the field of "public law," alongside similar disciplines like labor law and environmental law. Among the few health law centers at U.S. law schools, the Solomon Center is unique in its focus on the government's role in health care as well as health care business and physicians and scientists themselves. The Solomon Center distinguishes itself by doing what Yale does best: focusing on law as a tool to affect governance, industry, and the academy at the highest levels.
The Center's programming includes many course offerings, both academic and experiential; career planning; academic research, policy work and litigation briefs; and numerous high profile panels and conferences that bring academic, government, and business leaders in health care to the Law School. We host a steady stream of academic visitors from all disciplines to enrich our programming and course offers, and we actively support student research, field work, and publications. Our work is highly interdisciplinary. Building on established relationships with the Yale School of Medicine, Yale Cancer Center, Yale-New Haven Hospital, Yale School of Management, and Yale Interdisciplinary Center for Bioethics, the Center brings together all that Yale has to offer to make a difference both at Yale and beyond.

name: Solutions for Energy, Air, Climate, and Health
Somali Affairs at Yale
mission: To promote Somali affairs at Yale University through education, research, and programs.

name: Something Extra
mission: Something Extra has historically showcased women's voices on a broad range of self-arranged musical compositions. Now, SE welcomes and promotes all SSAA singers and continues to foster empowerment and community while sharing our music and passion.

name: Soul Food Club
mission: Members of the Soul Food Club will build a strong community through their shared interest of contemporary and ancestral soul food. The club acknowledges the longstanding significance of partaking in the cooking, dining, and learning of the greater culinary arts with respect to African-American cuisine. At times, other cultures with comparable dishes and culinary techniques will be highlighted in the interest of serving all members.

name: South Asian Graduate and Professional Association
mission:
SAGA shall be dedicated to creating and providing social, professional, and
intellectual forum for graduate and professional students interested in a range of
issues related to South Asia and South Asians.
SAGA shall also work to increase awareness of and to promote issues affecting
South Asia and South Asians at Yale University.

name: South Asian Law Students' Association
mission: The South Asian Law Students Association (SALSA) provides those interested in South Asian culture at Yale Law School a space to gather, create support networks, and form communities. We hope to instill awareness of the role of law students as future leaders who understand, care about, and support the history and concerns of the South Asian community.

name: Southeast Asian Movement at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: SEAM's mission is to create a multi-media presence at Yale through our online publication, educational videos, and hosting events that bring passionate Southeast Asianists together in inter-disciplinary and inter-regional engagement.

name: Special Needs Undergraduate Swim Lessons
mission: The goal of this organization is to facilitate rewarding relationships between undergraduates and local children with special needs, while ultimately creating a long lasting motivation within Yalies to give back to their community. We teach water safety skills and basic swimming to special children in the New Haven community.

name: Splash At Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Splash's mission is to increase students' excitement for learning by introducing them to topics beyond the scope of traditional school. By harnessing the passion and enthusiasm of Yale students, we hope to inspire middle- and high-schoolers to seek out further learning and see education as a fun, inviting process. We want to empower students by giving them full choice regarding their Splash day.

name: Spoon University
mission: Spoon is the food resource for the Yale Campus. Spoon is on a mission to make food make sense - our content is written by college students, for college students. On our site and in our magazine, you can find the simplest recipes, the most obvious hacks you can't believe you didn't know, and the best restaurants around campus that you haven't found yet. For many of us, this is the first time we're navigating our campuses or our kitchens on our own, and Spoon University is here to simplify and celebrate that. We offer opportunities for involvement through writing, photography, videography, and marketing and we publish editorial content regularly.

name: Sri Lankans at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of our organization is to bring together fellow Sri Lankans at Yale University in order to strengthen our bonds through celebrating our culture and sharing it with our peers.

name: STEM & Health Equity Advocates
mission: In recognizing the adverse, harmful, and even fatal effects of racism in STEM and healthcare, our mission is to implement anti-racist education for STEM and pre-health students, expand the History of Science, Medicine, and Public Health department, and actively support and collaborate with other student-led efforts to dismantle systemic racism at Yale University.

name: STEM Mentors at Yale - a graduate student organization
mission: Our mission is to encourage local high school students, especially underrepresented groups like women and minorities, to pursue careers related to STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics). To achieve this goal, we provide mentors for students and host a variety of public events throughout the school year. Our mentors help students to explore a variety of career options and to navigate the transition between high school and college.

name: Steppin' Out
mission: Step is an African American dance form developed first by South African miners as an alternative to drumming, a previously banned activity. There is a vibrant step dance tradition in the South, but in the Northeast many people have never even heard of it. Steppin' Out aims to share this great history and culture with the Yale community, both by making the otherwise unknown style visible in the first place and by celebrating the diversity of our membership.

name: Student Accessibility Services
mission:
The primary mission of Student Accessibility Services (SAS) is to facilitate individual accommodations for all students with disabilities throughout the entire University, and by so doing, work to remove physical and attitudinal barriers, which may prevent their full participation in the University community. Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and the Americans with Disabilities Act guide much of our work.
Often, the physical barrier is the easiest to remove - the attitudinal barriers are much more difficult. To create a university community, which is truly accessible and inclusive of all persons, including people with disabilities requires the participation of each member of the community. If you have any questions about accessibility or our office, please contact us.

name: Student Association of Thais at Yale
mission: The mission of SATAY is to serve as a community for Thai and interested Yale students and to share Thai culture to the broader Yale Community.

name: Student Flying Club at Yale
mission: The mission of the SFCY is to  build an active community of aviation enthusiasts by immersing members in the world of aviation.

name: Student Interest Group in Neurology - SIGN
Student National Medical Association/Latino Medical Student Association
Student Technology Collaborative (STC) of Yale IT
Taiwanese American Society
mission: The Taiwanese American Society at Yale (TAS) is dedicated to promoting awareness of Taiwan and Taiwanese American culture while fostering the Asian American community at Yale. Through cultural, political, and social events, we aspire to build a sense of cultural awareness and a spirit of kinship among students. TAS is non-exclusive and embraces with open arms all who are interested in joining the organization. Above all, TAS is a warm and diverse family of friends.

name: Students and Alumni of Yale
category: Leadership, Pre-Professional, Professional, Service/Volunteering, Social, Student Government
mission: STAY's mission reaches far beyond New Haven to shared interest groups (SIGs), Yale College classes, Graduate & Professional alumni associations, and regional Yale clubs around the world. Alumni provide the wisdom of educational, job, and life experience. Graduate and professional students offer career guidance to college students and energy to alumni. Undergraduates offer fresh perspectives and enthusiasm. STAY stands at the intersection of these talents and points the way for three Yale communities to form long-lasting, mutually beneficial relationships.

name: Students Demand Action at Yale
mission: Students Demand Action is working with students on campus and gun violence prevention leaders to bring the power of advocacy, research, and grassroots organizing to communities across the country

name: Students for Carbon Dividends
mission: The mission of S4CD is to catapult a free-market climate solution—specifically the Carbon Dividends Plan—into the national spotlight and open the door to bipartisan climate action.

name: Students for Sensible Drug Policy at Yale
mission: Students for Sensible Drug Policy is an international grassroots organization working to end the global War on Drugs. We provide harm reduction drug education on campus and organize at the university, city, and state levels to fight drug war-era hysteria and move toward policies grounded in evidence, science, compassion, health and human rights.

name: Students of Yiddish at Yale
mission: To provide opportunities for student engagement in Yiddish culture, history and literature with a focus on Yiddish-centered cultural events and meaningful engagement with the Yiddish language.

name: Study Abroad
mission:
Yale Study Abroad is here to guide you through the process of identifying the international experience that fits your goals and interests. Choose from hundreds of study abroad options, including Yale Summer Session Programs Abroad, Non-Yale Summer Abroad, and Year or Term Abroad.
→ studyabroad.yale.edu

name: Stuttering At Yale
mission: Our mission is to create a space on campus to share and celebrate our experiences as people who stutter, build community among stutterers at Yale and raise awareness about speech disfluencies.

name: Sube: Yale Latinx Pre-Professional Student Association
category: Entrepreneurial/Business, Pre-Professional, Science/Technology, La Casa  Affiliate Org
mission: Sube is aimed at uniting the Yale Hispanic/Latinx undergraduate community and empowering those in the community to cultivate their professional interests and leadership skills.

name: Supporting Student-Athletes at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: SSAY aims to support and provide a community for LGBTQIA+ student-athletes at Yale.

name: Sustainable Development in Latin America and the Caribbean Conference (SDLAC) SIG
Sustainable Fashion at Yale (SIG)
mission: Fostering a space on campus for those passionate about the state of the fashion industry and how sustainable solutions can make meaningful impact!

name: Symposia--A Yale Undergraduate Research Journal
mission:
Symposia is Yale's Premier Investigative Journalism group with a focus on academia and entrepreneurship in Health/Medicine, STEM, Social Sciences, and Humanities. This year we'll publish:
1) (New!) A video series profiling the diversity of labs and research centers on campus
2) Investigative journalism pieces and profiles showcasing the diversity of labs and research centers on campus and celebrating original undergraduate scholarship across all disciplines.
