We intend to expose readers to students and faculty who share a passion for research and cultivate an environment of collaboration and investigation at Yale.

name: Yale Undergraduate Veterans Society
mission: YUVS will advocate on behalf of Yale's undergraduate veterans regarding issues specific to that federally protected minority community. It will also provide a community for all who wish to support our mission.

name: TAMID Group at Yale
mission: TAMID Group is a nonprofit organization that develops the professional skills of undergraduate students through hands-on interaction with the Israeli economy.  TAMID integrates the next generation of entrepreneurs and business professionals with Israel through a comprehensive education curriculum, pro-bono consulting for Israeli startups, capital market investment research, and a summer internship program in Israel. TAMID has no political or religious affiliations.

name: Tangled Up In Blue
mission:
Tangled Up in Blue (TUIB) provides a musical space for students passionate about creating and sharing folk music. Through on-campus performances and tours, TUIB (pronounced twihb) shares that love of folk music with our larger communities, from Yale itself to the towns that members are from.
Our group has repertoire that ranges from the bluegrass tunes of the Appalachians to traditional Irish ballads, the folk-rock hits of Bob Dylan to the jams of Crosby, Stills, Nash, & Young, and Simon & Garfunkel.  We sing four-part folk harmonies and accompany ourselves on guitar, banjo, fiddle, viola, mandolin, and harmonica.

name: Taps at Yale - A Student Organization
mission: Taps at Yale allows dancers to continue to explore their love of Tap Dance and to share that love with the wider Yale and New Haven communities.

name: Tau Beta Pi Engineering Honor Society
category: Academic, Leadership, Pre-Professional, Professional, Science/Technology, Service/Volunteering
mission: Tau Beta Pi is the second-oldest honor society in the United States, with active chapters at 250 U.S. colleges and universities with a total initiated membership of more than 595,000. The society was founded when the nation's oldest honor society, Phi Beta Kappa, sought to restrict its membership to students in the liberal arts. Only the top one-eighth of juniors and the top one-fifth of seniors are eligible for Tau Beta Pi membership, with elections at Yale held once a semester. Yale Tau Beta Pi is devoted to acknowledging engineering excellence, giving back to the Yale and New Haven community, and fostering a sense of community in the engineering departments via mentorship opportunities and student-faculty dinners.

name: TEDx Yale - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The purpose of this organization shall be to promote the mission of TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) at Yale. As the synthesis of two intellectual and creative powerhouses, TEDxYale provides a learning environment for the Yale and surrounding New Haven communities based on the sharing of ideas and stories via the TED format.

name: Temporary Restraining Order Project
mission: The Temporary Restraining Order Project (TRO Project) staffs an office at the New Haven courthouse to assist individuals seeking temporary restraining orders. Students assist with completing paperwork and follow up to ensure that TROs are served and applicants return for their hearings.

name: The Arthur Liman Center for Public Interest Law
mission: The Liman Center promotes access to justice and the fair treatment of individuals and groups seeking to use the legal system. Through research projects, teaching, fellowships, and colloquia, the Liman Center supports efforts to bring about a more just legal system.

name: The Baker's Dozen
mission: The Baker's Dozen is an all-male undergraduate a Cappella group. In 2010, the Baker's Dozen formalized our commitment to spreading our passion for music by incorporating as a Connecticut non-profit (503(c)(3)) organization.

name: The Black Solidarity Conference at Yale
mission: The Black Solidarity Conference at Yale is a completely student-run annual conference held in February.  BSC is the largest undergraduate conference held at Yale University and it continues to grow each year! BSC invites over 700 undergraduates of of various races, religions, ethnicities, and communities to discuss issues pertaining to the African Diaspora. Through discussions, panels, networking, and social gatherings, students from across the country analyze issues affecting the Black/Afro-Diasporic community and explore solutions that can be implemented on their own college campuses.  In the past, the Conference has hosted Drs. Michael Eric Dyson, Angela Davis, Nikki Giovanni, and Cornel West as keynote speakers. We've also hosted artists such as J. Cole, Big Sean, Vic Mensa, and Phony Ppl as concert performers! In the following pages, you can discover how to register for conference and be a part of this amazing experience!

name: The Cinemat
mission: We aim to promote student filmmaking on campus, both through technical training and community building. We are committed to showcasing diverse stories and encouraging creativity and collaboration within the student body.

name: The Connecticut Hospice Advisory Board
mission: To create a lasting, positive relationship between Yale University and The Connecticut Hospice through a diverse team of graduate student consultants. The Board will consist of interested students from all health care or management related graduate programs and will attend to the various strategic planning and administrative needs of The Connecticut Hospice. The Connecticut Hospice will benefit from strategic recommendations and board institutional memory while students will benefit from meaningful project-based work.

name: The Conservative Party
mission: The Conservative Party is oriented toward the production of principled and profound leaders.

name: The Control Group
mission: Control Group meets on a regular basis to train and generate content for upcoming work. We draw from techniques and styles that are idiosyncratic to Control Group as well as from the expertise and experience of current members. Control Group is constantly redefining itself to address the interests of current members and the contemporary possibilities and challenges of live performance.

name: The Cortex Collective
mission:
Our mission is to foster dialogue, passion, and creation at the intersection of the arts and sciences for the Yale community. We hope to do so in the following ways:
1. Produce a magazine of work that bridges the arts and the sciences for the Yale community,
and for this magazine of work to be generated collaboratively by a team rather than in a dispersed format, thereby encouraging student collaboration across disciplines.
2. Cultivate a safe and welcoming home for passions and interests belonging to Yale students which express curiosity, intrigue, open-mindedness, and creativity.
3. Disseminate interdisciplinary attitudes and expertise at the intersection of the arts and sciences throughout the Yale community through external speaker events, workshops, newsletters & infographics, etc.;
4. Facilitate studios and workshop seminars  where members are invited to share  feedback in a collaborative, non-intimidating, respectful, and productive setting.

name: The Cucumber
mission: The Cucumber is a place for people of all levels of experience to do stand-up comedy.

name: The Dred Scott Society
mission:
The Dred Scott Society is a pan-affinity group for all students of color (BIPOC & PGM) who identify as being descendants of oppressed, colonized, segregated, and enslaved peoples. It is a space for these students
of color who have felt the consequences of de jure and de facto white supremacy in their own lives, and most importantly who are dedicated to confronting these forces, regardless of their specific race or nationality, in their time during and after law school.

name: The Egalitarian Society
mission: The Egalitarian Society is a space for discussions about egalitarianism that foregrounds imagining a better world. Through weekly close readings, guest lectures and alumni lunches, we hope to parse the intellectual roots of egalitarianism and apply them to real world action. Our goal is to foster community and solidarity, as well as promote education and awareness. We hope to build campus support for egalitarianism through our events, which are open to the entire Yale community.

name: The Elmseed Enterprise Fund
mission:
Founded by enterprising Yale undergraduates in 2001, Elmseed has become a valuable resource for over 500 New Haven businesses.
Elmseed is staffed entirely by Yale undergraduates dedicated to New Haven small business. We provide motivated entrepreneurs with access to one-on-one personalized consulting, business training, technical assistance, and a network of peer support. In doing so, Elmseed aims to empower entrepreneurs who lack the resources necessary to start or expand small businesses. Elmseed is committed to encouraging and enabling sustainable economic self-reliance in the greater New Haven area.

name: The Episcopal Church at Yale
mission: The Episcopal Church at Yale is worshipping community led by and dedicated to students.  Supported by our chaplain and the partnerships we have formed within Yale and New Haven, ECY exists to spiritually nourish all who attend.  Our mission is to welcome people into being inspired in worship, transformed in community, and impassioned for justice.

name: The Exit Players
mission: We learn and perform dynamic, long form improv. Exit strives to be as inclusive and open as possible, combating a history of comedy as a cis white male space. We are committed to portraying human, three-dimensional characters, not empty stereotypes, and creating on-stage worlds where marginalized voices are empowered, not silenced.

name: The Fifth Humour
mission: As Yale's oldest sketch comedy group, we write and perform original sketches on and beyond campus.

name: The Forest School
mission: Rooted in place-based experiential learning and rigorous research, The Forest School within the Yale School of the Environment educates scientists and practitioners to apply forest ecology and social dynamics in their work around the globe. We are a hub for connecting forests and people across disciplines, cultivating collaborations, initiatives, and research that underscore the importance of forests within the broader environmental field. As a school community, we train leaders in the field to be systems thinkers with dynamic and adaptive expertise, developing sustainable solutions for the critical challenges of our time.

name: The Forests Dialogue
mission:
Purpose: To contribute to sustainable land and resource use, the conservation and sustainable management of forests, and improved livelihoods by helping people engage and explore difficult issues, find collaborative solutions, and make positive changes.
Mission: To pursue our purpose through constructive dialogue processes among all key stakeholders, based on mutual trust, enhanced understanding and commitment to change. Our dialogues are designed to build relationships and to spur collaborative action on the highest priority issues facing the world's forests.

name: The Good Show
mission: To perform Late Night style comedy!

name: The Grant Hagan Society - a Yale Music Department Graduate Student organization
mission: The Grant Hagan Society is a graduate-student led affinity group to support people of color in the Yale Department of Music. We are deeply invested in the racial and ethnic diversity of the students and faculty of the department, as well as diversity broadly construed (gender, sexuality, [dis]ability, class, religion, etc.). The Grant Hagan Society strives to help foster a sense of camaraderie among people of color within the field of music studies, as we believe that belonging to an inclusive community contributes in important ways to a successful career path after graduate school, whether in the academy and beyond.

name: The Independent Party
mission:
The Independent Party of the Yale Political Union is the premier forum for free and authentic student debate at Yale. One of the founding parties of the Yale Political Union, the IP is easily the Union's largest party and the only one that adheres to no specific ideology or political viewpoint; instead we aim to foster robust, open, and wide-ranging political discourse.
Our weekly debates are open to the entire Yale community and address challenging political, cultural, and philosophical issues. Our debate format is easily accessible and relies on Robert's Rules of Order to ensure that all voices are heard and respected. We encourage everyone–the casual visitor and committed member alike–to ask tough questions, give speeches, and actively explore their own convictions. Recently, we have debated some of the following resolutions: Resolved: Kill the Death Penalty; Resolved: Hypocrisy is Not Immoral; Resolved: WikiLeaks is Good for America; Resolved: Go West, Young Man; and Resolved: Defund the Arts
The Independent Party's motto is "Hear All Sides," and this is an imperative by which we live. At our debates, you will find bold expressions of opinions from across the political spectrum. One could say that the IP is home to libertarians, socialists, neo-conservatives, hard-line moderates, and almost everything in between–but in fact, we are a group of students who resist the claustrophobic categories of "liberal" and "conservative" popular in today's politics and reject the partisan pressures that demand adherence to a mass-produced political platform, in favor of intellectually honest and authentic approaches to forming and evaluating our worldviews. In the Independent Party we believe that openness of mind is the truest mark of genuine intelligence.
Along with our debates, the Independent Party hosts a wide variety of social events throughout the academic year. Whether watching a movie, arguing over drinks, or toasting at Mory's, IPsters are always having fun together. As we like to say, we take our ideas seriously, but we don't take ourselves too seriously. The IP is one of the closest groups of friends you will find at Yale; the friendships formed in the IP stay with us forever.
We also go to New York City every semester to meet with prominent politicians, journalists, business people, artists, and media personalities. In recent semesters, we have meet with former New York Mayor Ed Koch, Obama Administration health care expert Dr. Ezekiel Emmanuel, Editor-in-Chief of The New Atlantis Eric Cohen, CEO of the New York Public Library Tony Marx, UN Ambassador John Bolton, Historian Eric Foner, and the late William F. Buckley, Jr.
"Yale," George Pierson famously said, "is at once a tradition, a company of scholars, a society of friends." The Independent Party is much the same. Please join us at one of our debates this Fall and learn firsthand what this party is all about.

name: The International Community @ YLS
mission: The International Community @ YLS is a group for all foreign and international students across all academic programs at Yale Law School. The group provides programming centered on career planning, immigration advocacy, and community building.

name: The Jackson School of Global Affairs
mission: The Jackson School of Global Affairs promotes education and scholarship on global affairs at Yale.

name: The Logos
mission: The Logos is a journal of Christian thought published each semester that seeks to stimulate discussion of a Christian worldview in a way that is relevant, accessible, and engaging to the Yale community.

name: The Moderate Party
mission: We, the Moderate Party, are a community devoted to political change. As such, we seek both to develop our Members as people and leaders, and to develop a new vision of practical, center-left politics. Our means are not only spirited discussion and formal debate of the politics and policies that divide our country but also collaboration with local leaders to produce something to show for our vision. We value pragmatic policy debate and discussions on salient political issues. We seek to bring our ideas to the outside world, and the outside world to best develop them. Together, we strive to advance the Party, the Yale Political Union, and this country.

name: The New Blue
mission: The New Blue brings together a diverse group of singers who perform SSAA music and who form lifelong connections to each other in the process.

name: The Odd Ducks
mission: Our idea is to create a hybrid organization of sketch and standup with an impact not only on campus, but beyond. This is the first of its kind on the Yale campus and provides room for students who can 1) either focus on stand up and sketch comedy directly, or 2) try their hat at both and not sacrifice one over the other. This also allows for a nice change of pace for our audience, who can watch two different forms of comedy in one show.

name: The Office of Sustainability
mission: The Yale Office of Sustainability is committed to advancing sustainability principles by fostering innovation, helping to streamline operations, and preparing tomorrow's sustainability leaders.

name: The Progressive Party
mission:
Originally founded in 1962, the Progressive Party is a forum and community for those across the Left to deepen their understanding of what they believe, why they believe it, and to be able to defend those beliefs.
We host weekly debates and dinners, in addition to other social gatherings and social action events.

name: The Purple Crayon of Yale
mission: We are an improv comedy group that performs long-form improvisational sets sometimes in the form known as the "Harold." Our mission is to laugh and spread laughter.

name: The Scandinavian Society
mission: To bring together Yale college students with roots or interests in Scandinavia.

name: The Society of Orpheus and Bacchus
mission: The Society of Orpheus and Bacchus travels the country and world to spread music and joy to all audiences while giving its members a chance to grow as musicians and people.

name: The Tory Party
mission: Debate society. Member of Yale Political Union.

name: The University Curlers at Yale Undergraduate Division
mission: This organisation has been formed to create opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students at Yale to jointly curl socially and competitively, to preserve the traditions of curling and to encourage the camaraderie and sportsmanship of the game. All graduate and undergraduate students at Yale University are invited to participate. This club will be an integration of collegiate curling within the USCA with traditional social and competitive aspects of curling which centre around the spirit of curling. The spirit of curling, specifically the canon of respect for others irrespective of their background, beliefs, gender, sexual orientation, disability or race, shall be honoured and actively pursued by all members.

name: The Urban Philanthropic Fund
mission: The UP Fund's mission is to educate Yale students about investment management and its social applications in the context of community development.  In order to accomplish this mission, we also aim to enable nonprofit organizations and social ventures to maintain or expand programs that benefit underserved residents of New Haven.

name: The Viola Question
mission: We are a group of improvisers and friends who aim to make you laugh.

name: The Whaling Crew
mission:
The Whaling Crew's mission is to build community around Yale Athletics, ultimately enhancing the Yale experience for student athletes and non-athletes alike.
We are a unified, organized student group dedicated to yelling too loud and heckling too obnoxiously at Bulldog athletic events.

name: The Women's Network
mission: The Women's Network at Yale is an intercollegiate organization focused on connecting and empowering women in the professional workplace, and creating a social community of ambitious, hard-working women.  We host career-focused events for women in all areas of study to be directly introduced to successful women in their fields and to hear from them in an open and candid discussion setting. We also host professional training bootcamps, career symposiums, networking events, Q&A panels, social events, and more. As an organization that hosts many large-scale events, we are able to differentiate ourselves by providing our members the opportunity to network across a much more extensive list and in many diverse areas. Our TWN Yale members become part of the greater TWN National organization, where we have over 30,000 members across the country and 142 chapters across college campuses. Ultimately, joining TWN will enable members to meet and connect with high-achieving individuals on both the Yale campus and around the nation, authentically network with powerful industry leaders, gain insight into traditional and unconventional careers, build confidence, gain leadership experience, and access exclusive internship and job opportunities.

name: Yale Journal of Law and Technology
mission: The Yale Journal of Law and Technology (YJoLT) offers a network of tech-focused law students and exposure to cutting-edge legal scholarship. If you are passionate about robotics, science, privacy and beyond, join our community!

name: The Writer's Room
mission: The mission of The Writer's Room is to provide an open, inclusive, and stress-free environment for individuals to engage with fellow lovers of literature through their creative work. The organization offers individuals a productive and enjoyable opportunity to write, edit, and share their creative work among an inspired and supportive community of their peers.

name: The Yale Alley Cats - An Undergraduate A Cappella Singing Group
mission: The Yale Alley Cats is a world-renowned undergraduate a-cappella group founded in 1943. Our mission is to sing wonderful music together, become better musicians through vocal performance and rehearsal, to share our music to Yale's campus and audiences across the world, and, most of all, to cultivate meaningful friendships that last a lifetime. Although initially founded as a Jazz group, our over-400-song repertoire ranges all the way from Harry Styles to Michael Jackson. As the first internationally-touring undergraduate group at Yale, The Yale Alley Cats has funded trips to Hong Kong, Sydney, Istanbul, and Paris, London, and Geneva on our most recent tour. We've had the pleasure of performing for icons such as President Barack Obama, collaborated with a Grammy-winning songwriter, and released several albums, with a new album coming this year! As one of Yale's oldest a-cappella groups, The Yale Alley Cats strive to uphold the strong tradition of a-cappella music that has become such a signature of Yale's student life.

name: The Yale Citations
mission: Using A Cappella as a medium, The Citations hope to foster musical camaraderie and performance opportunities for singers chosen through a competitive audition.

name: The Yale Ethnobotany and Mycology Society (YEMS) SIG
The Yale Globalist - An Undergraduate Publication
mission: The Globalist is Yale University's only undergraduate international affairs quarterly. The Glo is written, edited, and published entirely by students of Yale and is read all over the world. We aim to provide Yale students with international journalism experiences both in New Haven and abroad.

name: The Yale Herald Inc.
mission: The Yale Herald, a weekly Yale undergraduate publication, is nestled in the sweet spot between magazine and newspaper. Since 1986, the Herald has aimed to provide in-depth, analytical reporting and includes personal essays, interviews and profiles, culture articles, creative writing, reviews, humor, and feature coverage of campus and local happenings. With a circulation of over 2,000, the Herald is the second-highest circulated campus publication and is distributed free of charge throughout the Yale campus and New Haven businesses.

name: The Yale Historical Review: An Undergraduate Publication
category: Academic, Advocacy/Policy, Cultural, Leadership, Political, Publication
mission: The Yale Historical Review: An Undergraduate Publication exists to give undergraduates an opportunity to engage in the editorial process and have their exceptional work highlighted. In addition to introducing writers and editors to the peer review process that gives them access to faculty advising, the diverse nature of the Review gives an apt perception of the various experiences Yale history students have.

name: The Yale Journal of Human Rights: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: To encompass the discussions and forums about human rights under the lens of health, economics, identity, politics, historical trends, and technology. We aim to capture these debates about human rights in the past, apply them to current situations, and consider future possibilities.

name: The Yale Layer: An Undergraduate Publication
mission: The Yale Layer is a student run publication dedicated to issues of mental health and student well-being on Yale's campus. The goal of the publication is to give students a platform on which they feel comfortable voicing their stories.

name: The Yale Politic – an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of The Politic is to provide an outlet for politically-inclined students on campus to participate in political journalism, express political opinions, and be exposed to new political thought.

name: The Yale Political Union (Undergraduate)
mission: The Yale Political Union provides students with a non-partisan forum for parliamentary debate, as well as encourages the discussion of matters of public interest by other suitable means.

name: The Yale Record - An Undergraduate Publication
category: Arts: Visual Arts, Performance: Comedy, Publication
mission: Yale's undergraduate humor magazine. Making jokes since 1872.

name: The Yale Undergraduate Coalition for Advocacy and Innovation
category: Advocacy/Policy, Social, Tsai CITY Affiliate Org
mission: The Yale Undergraduate Coalition for Advocacy and Innovation (YUCAI) finds comprehensive, social impact solutions through collaborative ideation, while providing a union of unwavering support for its members.

name: The Yale Undergraduate Literary Society
mission: Emulating the seminar format, the Yale Undergraduate Literary Society aims to provide a space for those interested in conversations on topics and issues related to difference, culture, humanity, philosophy, history, and politics considered in mainly literary contexts. We practice articulating complicated ideas on issues members care about and teasing out left-over ideas from classes, events, and news. Speaker events consist of inviting Yale faculty, visiting authors, museum curators, etc. to lead discussions. People from all majors and all backgrounds are encouraged to join!

name: The Yale Undergraduate Prison Project
mission: YUPP is a student run social justice organization with over 150 members that engages in service and advocacy related to mass incarceration. Our mission is to challenge the structural inequities of the criminal justice system through weekly educational programs for incarcerated and formerly incarcerated individuals, community partnerships, and legislative advocacy.

name: The Yale Votes Initiative - A Student Organization
mission: Yale Votes is a non-partisan organization that strives to increase civic engagement among all Yalies, defend student voting rights, and make the voting process as accessible as possible. We understand that to live in a democracy is to live in a society that honors the liberty and dignity of all people. We advocate on behalf of democratic practices and principles with this broad understanding of democracy in mind.

name: The Yale Women's Center - An Undergraduate Organization
mission:
The Women's Center works across issues and identities toward collective liberation. Gender and sexuality have historically been central to our work and now serve as one of many points of entry into intersectional struggles and coalition building.
We seek to foster a self-critical and self-reflective community, intentionally directing our time, resources, and programming toward dismantling systems of oppression through education and action. We aim to provide a physical and intellectual space where all are able to collaborate, learn, and unlearn without judgment. We strive to make our work accessible to everyone who wishes to engage with it, firmly believing that this work cannot and should not be done in isolation.
The Women's Center may be spatially enclosed within and funded by Yale, but all work within the university is intertwined with New Haven. We strive to build a deep and long-standing relationship with the city: realizing our mission demands that our community and our efforts extend far beyond our campus.

name: There's Hope in North Korea
mission: ThiNK's mission is to provide a public platform of actionable discourse for activists and experts, as well as give a voice for defectors. We want to encourage our peers to engage in earnest discussions of how change might be effected. We seek a comprehensive understanding of North Korean issues, driven by a firm belief in the power and value of human rights. We look for avenues to positively engage with and empower the global North Korean community.

name: Thomas Swan Barristers Union
mission: The Thomas Swan Barristers' Union provides students with the opportunity to learn trial advocacy skills in an educational, fun, and competitive environment. Students act as attorneys and simulate a jury trial, preparing witnesses and writing and performing pre-trial motions, opening statements, direct and cross examinations, and closing arguments.

name: Thomistic Institute at Yale — Undergraduate Chapter
mission:
The Thomistic Institute exists to promote Catholic truth in our contemporary world by strengthening the intellectual formation of Christians at universities, in the Church, and in the wider public square. The thought of St. Thomas Aquinas, the Universal Doctor of the Church, is our touchstone.
The Thomistic Institute is part of the Pontifical Faculty of the Immaculate Conception at the Dominican House of Studies in Washington, DC.

name: Title IX Office
mission:
Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 is a federal law that protects people from sex and gender discrimination in educational programs and activities at institutions that receive federal financial assistance.  Title IX states that:
No person in the United States, on the basis of sex, shall be excluded from participation, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any educational program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.
Yale University is committed to providing an environment free from discrimination on the basis of sex or gender. Yale provides many resources to students, faculty, and staff to address concerns relating to discrimination on the basis of sex or gender in all aspects of the educational process.

name: Title IX Working Group
mission:
The Title IX Working Group is a group of students and administrators fighting gender-based violence and harassment on campus and beyond. We are working to create a safe, equitable space at the law school, and to address the systemic biases that often disadvantage women, people of color, LGBTQ+ people, people with disabilities, and members of other marginalized groups. In concert with Yale Law School's active student organizations, we strive to create a community that supports every student.
To further this goal, the Title IX Working Group advises the law school administration on policies and advances efforts to improve campus climate and promote gender justice. We engage locally—fostering inclusive pedagogy and providing resources for survivors of sexual assault or harassment—and globally—researching and weighing in on national conversations about gender violence.
In the past few years, we've delivered results, including rolling out a law-school wide survey of sexual harassment and violence, making gender equity a focus point in biannual course evaluations, and creating a peer-lead program to offer support and informal resources to all students. We also meet regularly with faculty and administrators to discuss student concerns.
If you have and questions or concerns, or if you would like to join the Working Group, please contact one of the co-chairs of the Working Group: Grace Judge, Evan Walker-Wells, or Noelle Wyman

name: Tommy Fund for Childhood Cancer
mission: This organization will exist as the undergraduate chapter of the Tommy Fund for Childhood Cancer which since 1953 has supported families whose children are undergoing cancer treatments at Smilow Cancer Hospital: https://tommyfund.org/. The Tommy Fund provides direct payment for rent, mortgage and utility bills so parents can take time off from work to tend to their child. The clinic sees several hundred newly-diagnosed children each year and treats more children with cancer than any other hospital in Connecticut. The undergraduate chapter will raise money, build a network of groups that support the Smilow Hospital Tommy Fund, and will raise awareness about the plight of families struggling with childhood cancer.

name: Trans@Yale: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The three goals of Trans@Yale are: to provide a safe space for transgender and/or non-binary students to form a community that provides emotional support and any needed medical advice; to work with the Yale administration to provide respect and support, individually and institutionally, for trans and non-binary students; and to engage with larger-scale sociopolitical advocacy and activism around issues affecting the trans community as well as other communities fighting for rights and recognition. The first goal will be achieved through hosting social events and meetings where students can be themselves and feel comfortable and safe, as well as hosting workshops and talks on key trans issues. The second goal will be achieved through student activism, and also by working with the Office of LGBTQ Resources and the Yale Administration to find and rewrite policies that currently exclude trans/non-binary students and/or make being trans and participating in a Yale-affiliated activity unusually difficult. The third goal will be achieved also through student activism, as well as collaboration with other on-campus organizations and New Haven groups.

name: Trans@YLS
mission: Our mission is to support the trans community at YLS by creating safe spaces, connecting members, and advocating for our needs.

name: Tropical Resources Institute
mission: Founded in 1983, the Tropical Resources Institute (TRI) is an interdisciplinary, non-degree-granting program located within the Yale School of the Environment (YSE). TRI serves to facilitate and support student research and outreach activities throughout the tropics, primarily through granting research fellowships. TRI works closely with YSE students, advising them on research design, proposal development, and field methods, as well as facilitating in-country collaborations and partnerships with organizations and institutions working in the tropics. Within the broader Yale community, TRI serves as a clearinghouse for research and educational activities pertaining to tropical countries, societies, and environments.

name: Tsai Center for Innovative Thinking at Yale (CITY)
Turkish Student Association of Yale College
mission: Yale Friends of Turkey is a student-run organization at Yale University that aims to connect a diverse group of members over topics related to Turkey and the Turkish Culture. Our activities involve cultural dinners with signature Turkish food,academic talks on Turkish politics, movie screenings and many other social gatherings.

name: U.S. Attorney's Office - Southern District of New York
U.S. Attorney's Office - Western District of Washington
U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York
U.S. Attorney's Office for the Central District of California (Los Angeles)
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

U.S. DOJ, Civil Division, Appellate Section
U.S. DOJ, Civil Division, Commercial Litigation Branch
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency - Office of Enforcement & Compliance Assurance
Ukraine House at Yale – an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Ukraine House at Yale – an Undergraduate Organization is a cultural student organization that seeks to educate Yale students about Ukrainian culture and history and to foster nonpartisan discourse about Ukraine-related issues. Ultimately, Ukraine House aims to strengthen the Ukrainian community on Yale's campus and connect all Yale students who are friends of Ukraine, whether they self-identify as Ukrainians or they simply have an interest in Ukraine, its culture, or history.

name: Unapologetically Jewish
mission: The mission of Unapologetically Jewish is to foster unity amongst people who value peace, love and respect for all people but especially Jewish People. Anyone who is anti-anti Semitism is welcome to join and learn more about Jewish people, the Jewish religion, Jewish spiritual, cultural, and social heritage.

name: Undergraduate Production
mission:
Undergraduate Production (UP) was established in 2000 to ensure safe practices in the planning, production, and presentation of undergraduate performing arts events. Over the subsequent years, Yale College's performing arts culture has grown to encompass over 400 events, 2,500 students, and 30,000 audience experiences annually.
Yale University has a vast and vibrant performing arts culture. Within this rich environment, UP works exclusively with Yale undergraduates to ensure that their work gets the attention and support it needs. UP provides training and technical support for comedy, dance, music, opera, spoken word, theater, and interdisciplinary performance genres. We work on everything from large-scale projects, such as operas featuring dozens of cast members and musicians, to informal poetry slams.
Regardless of scope and scale, all student productions must be planned and developed in a manner that ensures the safety of the production team and the audience. UP exists to fulfill this mandate as we support both the artistic vision and the highest level of safety for each undergraduate production.

name: Unitarian Universalist Student Group
mission: The Unitarian Universalists Student Group provides support, denominational fellowship, advocacy, and opportunities for education and theological reflection for Unitarian Universalist students at YDS, as well as Unitarian Universalist worship for the wider YDS community.

name: United Against Inequities in Disease
mission:
Our keystone objectives are to identify health inequities within New Haven through research and to implement projects with local organizations to lessen the impact of these inequities.
Through its event-planning and outreach, Yale UAID aims to bring New Haven-relevant public health discussions/information to Yale students and increase general awareness prevalence of health inequities in surrounding community, and bring health education/access to the New Haven public in need, whether that be in partnership with hospitals, clinics, non-profits, or schools in the area.

name: United Church of Westville
mission: United Church of Westville (UCW) is a student-led, pastor-resourced church. It is our mission to know Christ and make Him known. We aspire to live life together as a family, loving each other in grace and truth, reading and studying the Bible and experiencing the transforming power of the gospel.

name: West Campus Community - Student & Postdoc Committee & Fellows
category: Academic, Administrative, Arts: Visual Arts, Professional, Science/Technology
mission: To promote events and activities for the West Campus Community of Studtents, Scholars and Trainees, including those sponsored by The West Campus Student & Postdoc Committee, McDougal GSL West Campus Fellows and OCS West Campus Fellows. Yale people working or studying at West Campus are welcome to join!

name: United Students for Veterans' Health at Yale
category: Advocacy/Policy, Health/Wellness, Leadership, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Political, Service/Volunteering, Veteran/Military
mission: The mission of United Students for Veterans' Health (USVH) is to aid in caring for and enriching the lives of veterans all across the nation. Our most cherished goal is fostering friendships between patients and students. In these relationships, our volunteers give back to those who gave so much. We strive to create a world in which students actively engage with and learn from the significant life experiences of veterans and veterans benefit from the joy and enthusiasm of student volunteers.

name: University Church in Yale
mission:
The University Church in Yale is a student-focused church welcoming Christian students of all backgrounds, as well as staff, faculty, post-docs, parents, alumnus/a, parents, and our New Haven neighbors.
Our church life is centered around Sunday worship in Yale's historic Battell Chapel, which features beautiful music, thoughtful preaching, and the prayer of a diverse, faithful community. Outside of Sunday mornings, we have lots of fun together with retreats, study groups, meals, concerts, lectures and other events.
UCY is an open and affirming congregation; we welcome persons of any denominational background (or none), race, ethnicity, age, nationality, sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, or physical or mental ability. Whether you are a life-long Christian, a questioning Christian, or new to Christianity, we hope that you feel at home with us.

name: University Church in Yale Undergraduate Deacons
mission: We, the undergraduate deacons of the University Church in Yale, are committed to being an open Christian group that is welcoming to all people: undergraduate students of any denominational background (or none), race, ethnicity, age, nationality, sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, or physical or mental ability are welcome.  We strive to serve as leaders of the undergraduate members of the University Church, provide worship, social, study and service opportunities open to all undergraduate students, act as the "eyes and ears" of the University Church on campus, and collaborate with other religious groups.

name: University Curlers at Yale - Graduate Student Division
mission: We are a group of students who play the Olympic sport of curling. Our mission is to spread interest, knowledge, and participation in the sport to help the sport grow as a whole as well as to succeed at the National Curling Competition and develop friendships.

name: Urban Improvement Corps
mission: The mission of the UIC is to spark intellectual growth amongst urban youth. Through tutoring and entrepreneurship classes, the program seeks to assist students in achieving academic success, and to inspire inner-city students to succeed beyond the classroom and in the business world.

name: Urban Learning Community
mission: We examine the impacts of an 'urbanized' world, from effects on resources and biodiversity to public health and climate change.

name: Urban Resources Initiative
mission: Our mission is to empower and support communities in the restoration, stewardship and enjoyment of the urban forest and nature in New Haven.

name: User Experience Society
mission: User Experience Society, also known as Design at Yale (DAY), is an undergraduate design community and studio run from Yale. We empower Yale undergraduates through design education, enlighten them to the power of design, and nurture them to create meaningful products for the community. We are a creative community for all undergraduates interested in design and its intersections.

name: Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Interest Group
mission: Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Interest Groups (VESIG) provides students with early exposure to the specialty of vascular surgery and helps students get involved in research and training early in their medical career.

name: Y-Worldwide Cereal Appreciation Club - A Student Organization
mission: In order to broaden our academic and culinary horizons, we will attempt to taste various iconic cereals from around the world. While doing so, we will strive to understand the culture/territory which has produced such a cereal: with an emphasis on debate, analysis, research, and inferences about what may have spurred the producers to create such a cereal. While doing so, we also hope to make connections using the similarity of flavor profiles amongst different cultures such that we can gain a broader understanding of the society we live in.

name: Vida Volunteer
mission:
"To promote human and animal health by bringing together the efforts of students, communities and the local healthcare systems."
"To become leaders in the human and animal Health Promotion Movement, through service learning experiences in Central America."

name: Vietnamese Student Association
mission: To promote a strong Vietnamese cultural connection with Yale University and create a group of loving friends who share the common connection of being Vietnamese and/or loving Vietnamese culture and people.

name: Violence Intervention Training, Advocacy and Education
mission:
Mission Statement:
Empowering Change Through VITAE: Violence Intervention, Training, Advocacy, and Education
VITAE, the Violence Intervention Training, Advocacy, and Education initiative at Yale School of Public Health, is a beacon of transformative action. VITAE stands as a cross-disciplinary force committed to curbing violence and injury through comprehensive strategies. Our core purpose is to prevent violence and injury, fostering a society built on understanding, empathy, and proactive change.
In our inaugural year, we have outlined three foundational priorities:
Assess Need: Grounded in data and empathy, we identify the unique challenges our communities face to tailor our efforts effectively.
Define Scope: Precision guides impact. By focusing on strategic initiatives, we magnify our ability to effect lasting change.
Build Infrastructure: We lay the groundwork for sustained, scalable action, ensuring our impact reverberates across time.
Our vision unfolds through dynamic activities:
Lived Experience Forums: An enlightening platform for voices often silenced, fostering empathy and understanding around violence's aftermath.
SkillUp Workshops: We empower Yale's community and beyond with actionable tools, fortifying intervention strategies.
Advocate for Equity: From local policies to national discourse, we fight for equitable public health practices.
Collaborative Engagement: Partnering with student groups across Yale, we amplify our collective voice against violence.
Amplify Awareness: Collaborating with faculty, students and community voices, we expand awareness of violence's various forms and how to combat them.
Research Catalyst: Nurturing student research, we catalyze evidence-based solutions for lasting impact.

name: Visit New Haven  - Shopping, Dining, Attractions and Things to do in Greater New Haven
mission:
This is the official site for information, attractions and events in Greater New Haven, CT. There is something for everyone in the New Haven area. Whether you're a resident looking to discover new parts of the region for the first time, or a first-time visitor hoping to fit the "best of" into a day, weekend, week or longer, you can't go wrong. It's all waiting for you. So start exploring!+Please visit the Visit New Haven Website for everything you need to know about our region!
+Follow VisitNewHaven on social media, and subscribe to our Email Newsletter to get regular updates on events and attractions!

name: Visual Law Project
mission:
The Visual Law Project (VLP) curates workshops, lecture series, and visual media that foreground the increasingly important intersections between visual content and the law. We develop visual literacy within the YLS community and train law students to deploy visual content as a tool for advocacy.
Visual and digital technologies have transformed the practice of law.  Lawyers are using videos to present evidence, closing arguments, and victim-impact statements; advocates are making viral videos to advance public education campaigns; and scholars are debating ideas in a multimedia blogosphere.  Everyone's doing it.  But no one is really teaching it — or reflecting upon it.  We see training in visual advocacy — effectively evaluating and making arguments through videos and images — as a vital part of our legal education.
The Visual Law Project fosters a community of students invested in visual advocacy. We enable students to produce intellectually stimulating documentary films on legal issues to advance public debate. We organize an annual reading group centered on visual jurisprudence. We connect YLS students with innovative practitioners and thinkers through our speaker series. VLP operates both within and beyond the law school, and seeks to collaborate on interdisciplinary projects with graduate students in other programs.

name: Volunteers in Pediatrics
mission: To enrich the clinical experience and create a supportive environment for pediatric patients and their families

name: Walden Peer Counseling
mission: Walden Peer Counseling is an anonymous and confidential hotline and walk-in peer counseling service staffed by Yale undergraduates. We are available to talk about anything that's on your mind.

name: Water Learning Community
mission: This LC builds knowledge of the science, policy, and management of the world's water resources, while promoting their sustainable use and equitable access.

name: Water Protectors Legal Collective and Gulf Coast Center for Law and Policy
Whim 'n Rhythm
mission:
As of 1981, Yale's vibrant a cappella scene featured a dozen underclassman groups of every variety. However, seven senior women felt that a key part of their musical experience was missing – a senior group. These seven seniors founded Whim n' Rhythm as an answer to the decades-old tradition of The Whiffenpoofs. Thirty-six years later, the 13 singers of Whim n' Rhythm represent the best and most experienced female musicians of the senior class.
Each year, Whim has continued to grow into a full-force presence on Yale's campus and on both the national and international stages. The group tours domestically and in the greater New England area yearly, visiting locations from New York and Los Angeles to Hong Kong and Cairo, and recently founded a full-fledged Alumnae Board to help build the group's legacy from beyond Yale's campus. Post-commencement, the group traditionally takes a five-to-seven week World Tour, hitting nearly every continent.
Prospective singers audition in the spring of their junior year to be tapped into Whim for their senior year the following fall. Whim represents nearly every underclassman singing group, a variety of residential colleges and academic majors, and hometowns ranging from coast to coast.

name: Wilderness Medicine Interest Group
category: Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Science/Technology, Sports/Outdoors, Special Interest
mission: To help connect members of the Yale medical community who share an enthusiasm for the outdoors, as well as host medical training related to the exploration of the wilderness.

name: William F. Buckley, Jr. Program
mission: The mission of the William F. Buckley, Jr. Program is to promote intellectual diversity at Yale University. We aim to expand political discourse on campus and to expose students to often-unvoiced views. We believe that ideas have consequences and that genuine intellectual diversity is essential for advancing critical inquiry and avoiding ideological complacency. Our hope is that by providing a home for a diverse collection of serious conservative thought we can provide a forum for Yale students to consider and examine a range of political philosophies to which they are rarely exposed. As such, the purpose of this program is to foster open political discussion and intellectual engagement on campus.

name: WISAYale - a Student and Postdoc Organization
mission: As WISAY (Women and Gender Minorities in Science at Yale), we are dedicated to promoting the interests of female, transgender, and non-binary scientists and advocating for gender equality in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM). Historically, only a small fraction of science degrees were awarded to women, but in recent decades, women's overall participation STEM fields has steadily increased. Today, women earn half of all bachelor's degrees in science. The involvement of women and gender minorities in advanced study and careers in STEM fields continues to grow. However, women are still underrepresented in many STEM fields and face significant challenges at the highest levels of these professions. WISAY seeks to help overcome these disparities by supporting women and gender minorities at all career levels through mentoring, networking, career development, and community building.

name: Women & Gender Minorities in CS
mission: The mission of WGiCS is to empower, inspire, and celebrate women and other gender minorities in computer science.

name: Women and Gender Minorities in Physics
mission: Women in Physics is an organization committed to the advancement and recruitment of women in physics by helping to foster an inclusive and supportive social and academic environment.

name: Women In Chemistry
mission: The purpose of WiCh+ is to help foster a positive and inclusive atmosphere within the chemistry major at Yale. Our objective is to establish a network of support and a sense of community among peers in the chemistry department, with the intent to develop effective academic and professional advising resources for women and other minorities pursuing chemistry at Yale.

name: Women of Color Collective
mission: The Women of Color Collective is an affinity group for women of color and persons of color belonging to traditionally under-represented gender identities. We provide social support, mentorship, and community.

name: Women Who Weightlift
mission: WWW supports women in becoming healthier, happier, and stronger both inside and outside of the gym by creating a judgment-free environment teaching weightlifting techniques.

name: Y2Y New Haven
mission: Y2Y New Haven's mission is to employ a youth-to-youth model to provide a safe and affirming environment for young adults experiencing homelessness.

name: Women's Leadership Initiative at Yale - an Undergraduate Organization
mission:
The purpose of WLI is to empower women, promote and celebrate women's leadership at Yale and beyond, create an inclusive space where all are welcome, to place gender equity at the forefront of campus culture, facilitate discussion and action, and to create opportunities for women to take leadership roles on and off campus.
The mission of WLI is to connect and support women, develop future women leaders, and equip them with tools to succeed through professional, educational, and social activities. We strive for WLI to be a space where all women-identifying persons and allies can find community and empower one another.

name: Woodbridge Fellowship Applications
mission:
Established in 2005 by President Richard C. Levin, the Woodbridge Fellowship introduces recent Yale College graduates to the work and administration of Yale. The fellowship provides valuable professional experience for potential careers in higher education and non-profit organizations, particularly for recent graduates belonging to minority communities currently underrepresented in university administration.
Fellowships are full-time paid positions in the offices of university leaders, who take active interest in fellows' professional development. Fellows directly report to senior members of their offices and work with a variety of university staff, at all levels. Fellows most often combine day-to-day duties with responsibilities for specific projects that utilize their research abilities and other higher-level skills. Organizational and writing skills are particularly valuable, as is the ability to work well with multiple constituencies: staff of all kinds (clerical, technical, service, maintenance, managerial, and professional), faculty, alumni, and students.
Fellows meet regularly together, including for lunchtime conversation with the president, provost,  secretary, and other university leaders. These conversations about roles and responsibilities, and the career paths that led people into academic administration, give fellows a broad understanding of many facets of working in higher education.

name: Woodworking SIG
mission: To facilitate lifelong, fulfilling connections between students and forests by providing space for students to explore working with wood. To build community across all degree programs, class years, and academic interests, as well as with artisans in the broader New Haven community, connecting all of these groups more closely with each other and with trees and forests.

name: WORD: Performance Poetry
mission:
WORD is Yale's oldest and hypest spoken word group. We are a community of writers dedicated to sharing performance poetry with the Yale community, New Haven, and beyond. We organize performances on campus, conduct workshops with K-12 schools, and create collaborative art with other student groups. As a resident group of the Afro-American Cultural Center at Yale, we recognize the Black legacies that gave rise to spoken word and aim to extend those legacies to upcoming writers of all backgrounds during their four years at Yale.
https://wordatyale.com

name: Working Women's Network
mission: WWN provides programs and resources to Yale's women employees to help them pursue personal and professional goals– enhancing their individual success furthers the advancement of the university.

name: Writers Workshop
mission: To foster the creative writing juices of interested students and share their original work for avid appreciation and helpful critique.

name: Y Pop-UP
mission: We aim to help our members discover new cooking techniques, connect with other students interested in food, and promote cuisines and food cultures that are healthy and sustainable for individuals and the planet. We operate a full service, student run pop-up restaurant every other Friday open to Yale students, parents, friends, and professors.

name: Y-BioIncubator: A Student Collaborative
category: Academic, Entrepreneurial/Business, Medical/Nursing/Public Health, Science/Technology, Tsai CITY Affiliate Org
mission: Y-Bio hopes to unite the Yale-connected undergraduate, graduate, and professional engineering communities by providing a space for those interested in pursuing biological innovation in the health and medical fields. We want to give biological innovation a prominent stake on this campus. We will provide professional development workshops for these students, weekly lectures to expand their knowledge of current bio-innovations, plan trips to local biotech/medtech companies, and collaborate with CBIT/Tsai CITY to bring more medical technology creation resources to undergraduates. Lastly, we will provide students the opportunity to be involved in year-long medical device/global health technology projects, focused on mechanical devices, that will be vetted with CEID staff and CBIT.

name: Yale Anti-Gravity Society - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Yale Anti-Gravity Society aims to bring together jugglers and people with other circus-related talents of all skill levels so that we may learn from one another and grow as entertainers and performers. Juggling along with other circus arts is intrinsically a group activity, and we aim to create a supportive space where anyone with any interest in such activities can share their passion with other like-minded individuals and possibly collaborate on performances.

name: Yale Ace/Aro Space: Asexual/Aromantic Student Organization
mission: The ace/aro community is underrepresented, even within broader Queer spaces. Those who identify on the ace/aro spectra often feel isolated and lack a community of people with common experiences. Being part of a community can help individuals better understand their own identities and improve their overall sense of belonging while at Yale. Ace/Aro Space aims to serve as a community for those on the ace/aro spectra, with a secondary goal of raising awareness and increasing visibility for the ace/aro community within the broader Yale community and beyond.

name: Yale Aerospace Medicine Student and Resident Organization
mission:
We are Yale's chapter of AMSRO, the Aerospace Medicine Student and Resident Organization. AMSRO is part of the larger Aerospace Medicine Association (AsMA), which is the world's largest organization dedicated to aerospace medicine. We invite all Yale medical students to join us. We offer valuable networking opportunities through our speaker series, journal club, access to national membership benefits, scholarships, conference participation, finding aerospace medicine research opportunities, and connecting with AMSRO and AsMA members across the world. Whether you're an aspiring spaceflight surgeon or completely new to this fun specialty, this group has something to offer to everyone.
NOTE: Due to administrative constraints, participation in this group is limited to medical students; residents will not be able to join.

name: Yale African American Affinity Group
mission: YAAA strives to provide opportunities for staff to engage, build community and make connections at Yale and the broader New Haven community.

name: Yale African Students Association
mission: The Yale African Students Association (YASA) is an undergraduate student organisation at Yale University, registered with the Yale College Dean's Office (YCDO). YASA is an organisation established to convene a community of African students, both graduate and undergraduate, on Yale's campus, to discuss and raise awareness of pertinent issues on the continent, and to attend to the specific needs and interests of African students at Yale.

name: Yale Albanian Student Society
mission: The Yale Albanian Student Society hopes to bring together students interested in aspects of Albanian culture. We also hope to strengthen the Albanian community at Yale.

name: Yale Alternative Investments - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: YAI focuses on providing members experience in alternative investing: private equity, venture capital, real estate, and hedge funds. Through working on projects with established funds, members are given student internships, acquiring valuable hands-on financial experience while gaining insight into the mechanics of alternative investing.  Beyond project-based learning, YAI seeks to pursue deeper into the alternative investment space by inviting guest speakers and providing exclusive opportunities to network with industry professionals.  As Yale's first and only finance organization centered solely on alternative investing, YAI offers an unparalleled experience to contribute to multi-million and billion dollar investments as an undergraduate.

name: Yale Alumni Association (YAA) Activities - for Continuing and Graduating Yale Students
mission: Yale Alumni Association is eager to encourage communication and connection among Yale graduates through online resources, clubs and events in person and virtually around the world. Yale Alumni Association hopes to provide a lifetime of valuable ways to stay connected to Yale and creates special events to connect current and soon-to-graduate students and alumni for networking and career development.

name: Yale Alumni Club of New Haven - Current Yale Students can join for Local Alumni Networking & Events
mission: The Yale Club of New Haven is the official alumni group for all alumni and current students in Greater New Haven. If you are a current student, a soon to graduate or recent graduate, join the YCNH to meet and network with alumni, attend social events and activities and get to know your hometown Yale Alumni group. The Yale Club of New Haven welcomes alumni, current students, faculty, staff, and friends to become members. Graduate Student membership is FREE!

name: Yale Alumni Fund Student Ambassadors
mission: YAFSA is a group for students who love Yale. YAFSA partners with the Alumni Fund to promote giving to Yale. The student ambassadors share with their classmates the importance of philanthropy and spread the word about how gifts from alumni make the Yale College experience better. YAFSA welcomes students from all class years and offers educational and social events as well as opportunities to network with Yale alumni, faculty, and staff. YAFSA members can gain experience in marketing, communications, and the nonprofit sector while joining with friends and fellow students to support the Yale Alumni Fund.

name: Yale Animal Law Society
mission: The Yale Animal Law Society, a member of the Student Animal Legal Defense Fund, works to reduce animal suffering by providing resources and events related to animal law to the law school community. We welcome all who are interested in developing legal, policy, and community-based strategies to protect animals.

name: Yale Armenian Network: an Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Yale Armenian Network is an undergraduate student association that fosters and promotes Armenian culture and heritage to the Yale community. Furthermore, the Armenian Students' Association shall raise efforts to promote positive social interactions among Armenian students at Yale.

name: Yale Artificial Intelligence Association - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: Our mission is to accelerate the development of AI for the benefit of humanity and create the next generation of AI leaders at Yale. We meet weekly to discus, learn, and deploy the cutting edge of AI for the benefit of the Yale community and the world.

name: Yale Artists Cabaret: An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The Yale Artists Cabaret (YAC) cultivates community and connection among the undergraduate performance artist circles on campus by providing frequent, collaborative, experimental, and accessible performance opportunities.

name: Yale Athletics - Student Promotions
mission: The Official Page for \

name: Yale Ballroom Dance Team and Club
mission: YBDT focuses on providing an encouraging and accepting environment for everyone. We organize practices and lessons, taught by veteran team members and professional instructors, catered to all skill levels from newcomers to champions. Everyone is welcomed and no prior dance experience is required! Members have the opportunity to participate in competitions and showcases each semester. Sign up here for more info: https://forms.gle/svBcqJQCpG4acDAQ6

name: Yale Bengali Student Association
mission: YBSA seeks to showcase our Bengali identity to the broader Yale community. We intend to provide students with a community, a home away from home, and a platform to discuss culture, politics, and current affairs.

name: Yale Biology and Biomedical Sciences Diversity and Inclusion Collective (YBDIC) - a Graduate Student Organization
mission: The Yale BBS Diversity and Inclusion Collective (YBDIC) is committed to fostering the intellectual and personal growth of underrepresented backgrounds in the BBS. Our central mission focuses on a four-pronged approach: engagement, empowerment, outreach, and advancement.

name: Yale Biomedical Chinese Students and Scholars Association
mission: Yale Biomedical Chinese Students and Scholars Association is an organization for intellectual exchange and resource sharing between hundreds of Chinese students and scholars in the biomedical field.

name: Yale Biomedical Engineering Student Society
mission: The Yale Biomedical Engineering Society aims to increase awareness of the possibilities available through biomedical engineering, an interdisciplinary field in which the principles of basic science and engineering are applied to medicine. We hope to provide students at Yale with access to applied biomedical engineering in both academia and industry. We serve as a support network and forum for all biomedical engineering students to ask for advice or express their concerns in hopes of creating a strong, integrated major.

name: Yale Biotech Club - For Students & Affiliates
Yale Black Law Students' Association
mission: The Yale Black Law Students Association (BLSA) is a student organization composed of Yale Law School students concerned with issues affecting members of the African Diaspora. The purpose of BLSA is to support and advance the interests of its members and the broader Black community.

name: Yale Black Postdoctoral Association (YBPA)
mission:
The Yale School of Medicine Black Postdoctoral Association (YBPA) addresses the unmet needs of Black postdocs and focuses on the success and well-being of Black postdocs by taking the necessary steps to generate positive experiences in academia and elsewhere.
The organization works harmoniously with the Yale Postdoctoral Association (YPA); however, extends its objectives to address issues specific to Black postdocs that are often overlooked, such as representation and visibility, resource availability and opportunities for career development, sense of community and support, and retention.

name: Yale Black Seminarians
mission: Yale Black Seminarians is a faith-based, student-led organization committed to enhancing the lives of black students at Yale Divinity School. The mission of the Yale Black Seminarians serves the entire Yale Divinity School community with a committed focus on mobilizing the presence of black students through advocacy, faith and the pursuit of justice. Activities have included the Fall Revival, the Martin Luther King Day Worship Service, the Angel Tree Project at Christmas, and the Parks-King Lecture in the Spring. As an integral part of the YDS Community, the Yale Black Seminarians remain committed to diversity among both students and faculty.

name: Yale Black Women's Coalition - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of Yale Black Women's Coalition is to provide an ever-evolving, safe, and welcoming space to unite Black women and nonbinary folks in the Yale community. The coalition strives to be a community-led space that is inclusive of and elevates marginalized groups within our community with the recognition of intersectional identities.

name: Yale Blockchain Club - A Student Organization
mission: Our mission is to educate, empower, and bring together the next generation of Yalies through blockchain technology. We hope to build a community of driven and innovative students who want to build a better future.

name: Yale Breakers - an Undergraduate Organization
mission: Breaking (or breakdancing) is an athletic dance form rooted in hip-hop culture. Yale Breakers provides scheduled breaking practices and rehearsals. We also organize dance events, host workshops, and enter in national breaking competitions.

name: Yale Buddhist Student Community
category: Cultural, Health/Wellness, Religious/Spiritual, Cultural: Mixed Race
mission: Our organization aims to provide an ecumenical space for Buddhist study and practice which is accessible and valuable both for experienced practitioners and beginners looking to learn more.

name: Yale Cake Club — A Student Organization
mission: Yale Cake Club is an undergraduate organization that will foster camaraderie and fellowship among those with a shared love of cake. It seeks to build a community around the famed dessert staple in countries around the world and will be a haven for the sweet-toothed, collaborative undergraduates across campus. The club will also be a resource for those seeking to explore their culinary interests at Yale, host dining events for their peers, and build an institutional culture of cake

name: Yale Cancer Student Interest Group
mission: The Cancer Student Interest Group (CSIG) works closely with the Yale Cancer Center to expose students to oncology and the oncological subspecialties. We coordinate events that seek to connect students with ongoing research, faculty mentors, and shadowing opportunities.

name: Yale Caribbean Students' Organization
mission: The Yale Caribbean Students' Organization (CSO) aims to create a space on Yale's campus for the celebration of the rich and diverse cultures of the Caribbean region and its many diasporas.

name: Yale Center for Asylum Medicine
mission: The Yale Center for Asylum Medicine conducts forensic medical interviews and evaluations for asylum-seekers referred to Yale by regional legal groups and community organizations.

name: Yale Center for Business and the Environment
mission: To educate and inspire interdisciplinary leaders through business solutions to systemic environmental problems.

name: Yale Center for Faith and Culture
mission:
We seek a world in which everyone can take hold of a life worthy of our humanity.
Our purpose is to help people envision and pursue lives worthy of our humanity, through discerning, articulating, and commending visions of flourishing in light of the life and teaching of Jesus Christ and fostering truth-seeking conversations among the contending visions in our world today.

name: Yale Center for Natural Carbon Capture
Yale Children's Theater - An Undergraduate Organization
mission: The mission of Yale's Children's Theater is to share the joy of theatre arts with Yalies and New Haven youth.

name: Yale Civil Rights Project
mission: The Yale Civil Rights Project is an organization for students working collaboratively with non-profit organizations such as the ACLU, Know Your IX, and National Employment Law Project on legal research projects related to civil rights in the areas of civil liberties, critical race theory, economic justice, LGBTQ rights, racial justice, and women's rights.

name: Yale Club Cycling Team
mission: To develop competitive and ethical racers, enthusiasm for riding, equality in racing, and foster a local biking community.

name: Yale Club Equestrian Team
mission: The purpose of this team is to provide the opportunity for Yale students to compete in IHSA horse shows and to learn about equitation and horsemanship in a safe and supportive team environment.

name: Yale Club Indoor Climbing Team
mission: YCT's mission is to provide a community for climbers at Yale and to provide resources for competition climbers at Yale. We welcome all students, regardless of prior experience, to join our team.

name: Yale Club Kendo Team
mission: Yale Kendo seeks to teach the practice of Kendo in the Yale Community. Kendo (the way of the sword) is a martial art based on traditional Japanese swordmanship.

name: Yale Club Men's Soccer (C-2) Team
mission: Our mission is to play the beautiful game beautifully while building a team whose chemistry transcends the boundaries of a soccer field.

name: Yale Club Men's Ultimate Frisbee Team - Süperfly
mission: We are a sports team that exists to teach the sport of ultimate at a high level to all of our players, no matter what their athletic/ultimate backgrounds. Additionally, we strive to succeed competitively while staying true to the values of the international ultimate community that include gender equity and spirit of the game.

name: Yale Club Men's Water Polo Team
Yale Club Muay Thai Kickboxing Team
mission: The Muay Thai Kickboxing Club aims to provide a community where Yale undergraduate and graduate students can safely learn the Muay Thai style of martial arts for recreational and self-defense purposes.

name: Yale Club Running Team
mission:
Yale Club Running welcomes all undergraduates (and graduate students) to run with us as a group. We offer multiple pace groups every day, and are far more focused on running together than running "fast." We do not hold try-outs, we do conduct organized -- and completely optional, occasionally overnight -- trips to cross country meets in the fall and track and marathon events in the spring. Track and other running workouts are held twice a week, but like all YCR events, workouts are totally optional. Alternate runs will always be available on workout days.
We're a friendly group, with a wide array of Yale experiences and backgrounds.
Join us to see Yale and New Haven in a new way!

name: Yale Club Swim Team
mission:
Yale Club Swimming is a team of students from all corners of
campus life, with any range of experience, who come together due
to their love of swimming and the close-knit, family environment
that they find.

name: Yale Club Synchronized Swimming Team
mission: Our goal is to provide a space where people of all experience levels can join and learn how to synchronized swim and to also create a fun and supportive community.

name: Yale Club Tae Kwon Do Team
category: Cultural, Health/Wellness, Performance: Other, Service/Volunteering, Sports/Outdoors
mission: Club Taekwondo at Yale is a co-ed sports club that offers a dynamic Korean martial arts experience for undergraduate students, graduate students, and Yale faculty. Club TKD has operated for almost 40 years at Yale and provides a welcoming community and training environment where students can learn, grow, and compete at various levels of competition. Through rigorous training, members develop physical fitness, self-defense skills, and mental discipline. The club emphasizes technique, sparring, and forms to enhance students' overall athleticism and confidence.

name: Yale Club Triathlon Team
mission: We are an all-inclusive group of undergraduate and graduate students who enjoy the sport of triathlon. We strive to create an environment where athletes of all skill levels can receive professional coaching and training in the sport they love. We also work hard to make an otherwise very expensive and elite sport affordable and accessible to students. Join us for fun swim/bike/run practices - no previous experience needed!

name: Yale Club Women's Rugby Team
mission: We are the Yale Women's Rugby Football Club! We come from all walks of life, and all joined rugby with varying experience (majority had never played) but eager to meet new people, and learn a new sport with fitness-minded people. We like to say that we are the fittest team on campus :)

name: Yale Club Women's Ultimate Frisbee Team
Yale Club Women's Water Polo Team
Yale Journal on Regulation
mission: The Yale Journal on Regulation (JREG) is a biannual student-edited law review covering regulatory, administrative, corporate law topics. It is the top-ranked journal in the fields of corporate, administrative, bankruptcy, and commercial law in the United States.

name: Yale Club Wushu and Chinese Kung-fu Team
category: Cultural, Performance: Other, AACC Affiliate Org
mission:
The Yale Wushu team seeks to better its members in practice; by gaining focus and self-control
through intense training. Members hope to achieve self-mastery that will translate into respect
and compassion for others both inside and outside of the training hall.
Yale Wushu also seeks to better its community. The Yale Wushu team has been blessed by
many opportunities to spread the message of peace and nonviolence that lies at the center of
the word "wushu." Our classmates at Yale will go on to be leaders in their respective fields; it is
our hope that during our time here we succeed in spreading this message of peace to them. We
are also trying to spread this message to the city of New Haven.
